use a hospital bed- no more losing items.  Attach a canister, now you don't have to scramble to find your remote, or cell phone or a pen in the sheets, or worse, on the floor!
play outdoor sports - how much did you pay for that bag or that jacket? Don't put them on the ground again, use the handle as a hook and you have a portable, quick and simple solution.  Also good for keeping wandering hands out of reach of valuables and ensuring that you can spot your bag from across the court!
do winter chores - hate getting ice melt on your gloves or hands? Attach a coffee can or such and scoop it up. You can even keep your gloves on!


Add-a-Handle: to pull a family together This project spans two generations.  Mike Payne is the first generation.  He is the "Inventor" - he has been a bit of a frustrated Engineer all his life.  Not being a book trained designer, he works old school.  He waits for something to annoy him, then he works out a solution.  For the most part it stops there.  He may make a few prototypes, share them with people he likes, then move on to some other irritation. Tara (Payne) Vallin is the second generation.  She gets frustrated when all these great work-arounds just sit around.  This time she decided to do something about it!  She has picked up the gauntlet and is going to prove that a good idea should be shared.  And she will further prove that there is nothing unethical about making some money along the way!

The motivation behind
the original design was simple.  Mike is handy around the house: building
things, lots of repairs and painting.  He has NEVER liked painting the trim
work.  He has found over the years that after not-so-long his hands and
fingers would cramp from holding the quart size paint can.  He bought all
the gadgets on the market and none of them suited all his purposes - easy to use,
easy to clean, easy to store, saves time, saves money- and most important - no annoying stress on his
body.  His first solution was to use an empty plastic coffee can.  It
was lighter, and the cramping took quite a bit longer to start, but there it
was.... The next stage was to pick up the commercial pail that had a handle
built in, but his wife never had any single-color paint projects.  So, then
there had to be multiple pails and what about all the cleaning in-between as he never remembered the liners when at the store.  Soon
after, old beer pitchers started disappearing around the house.  His first
prototype showed up about two years ago.  At first, he was content filing
the patent paperwork (not his first) and trying to sell the whole
kit-and-caboodle to one of the major paint companies. 
Tara on the other
hand-le saw the full potential of this latest work-around.  It had so many
more practical uses than merely painting trim.  Unfortunately, Tara has
had some personal tragedy and has seen first hand what a God-send this
solution could be for folks with physical limitations.  But then, as her
perspective changed, so did her vision.  No longer limited to paint cans
and hospital beds...it became a go-to-tool for so many other everyday uses. She
approached Mike and said, "I want to make this happen..." He said,
"...run with it!" He filed the final Patent paperwork and they were on their way.
This is what we have done...
Mike made a variety of prototypes early on, and from there Tara did her research,
                  
 received tons of feedback and did lots of
testing with her own prototypes. Tara, like her Dad, is handy and a problem
solver, so she learned how to make her own prototypes. Through the
many stages of this process she has been able to make her own temporary molds
with a great product called Smooth-On. This allowed her to re-design as needed. It also allowed her to create a number of repeat handles in order to have them tested by people who would most likely use them once commercially available.  It has been very important to make sure they remain practical, comfortable and functional.    Tara began
working with Eric Fasser a Design Engineer to tweak the Add-a-Handle so that
it would be ready to take it to an injection molder and begin production. Once Eric completed the initial drawings several very affordable 3D-prints were made locally by Ed Hebel at Free Thought Designs. 
            



This afforded us the opportunity to experiment with the future assembly of the handle as well as to see and feel the changes that were made quickly and cost-effectively.  As one of our primary goals was to keep the product in
the USA, we thought why not keep the product truly local, and start with companies in
our home state of NY?  As a single mom this also means Tara could spend more time with her little daughter as
well!  Once the material for Add-a-Handle was
chosen, it limited the companies available and she began working with one.  They were not the right fit and after months
of going back and forth it came to a parting of the ways.  Lessons learned.  But since We Have
it Handled, we will keep on trucking along! 


This is where we are at...

Currently, we are engaged in talks with a new local company, and getting their feedback on how to take
this full speed ahead. However, we are not limiting ourselves and have quotes from others as well.

We have several goals
ahead of us:

Secure a new Injection Mold Company, preferably local
Create a great following of people who want to see
     Add-a-Handle succeed - Let's go Viral!

Gain media coverage to get the word out
Get the Metal Mold made
Cast high quality products...here in the USA
Display and present at the National Hardware Show, in Las Vagas, May 2015
Have our Indiegogo campaign go above and beyond our goal 
Get all our amazing backers their Perks!
Finalize packaging
Begin selling Add-a-Handle via our website and Amazon
Acquire purchase orders so Add-a-Handle gets into the brick 'n mortar stores and sells off the shelves!
Be another American woman-owned business success story!
Start again with our next product…

Crowdfunding is a
great means of getting Add-a-Handle the financial support it needs, but it is a
lot of work and that is why we have brought in CrowdfundBuzz. We know we cannot
do this alone and that is why we also need your support, financially and/or by your word of mouth and posting.  We truly
believe that Add-a-Handle can help so many, please Pay it Forward by spreading the
word, it might be because of you that someone else gains a little more ease in their day!
 


Where the funds have come from and where your funds will go…
Tara was a CFO before getting married
and is always running the numbers to make sure they work and that this is
financially feasible.  Rest assured, the funds will be accounted for and applied to get this product off the ground!
Currently, Tara has been funding We Have it
Handled Corp with her own funds. She had stopped working when she and Guillaume
got married.  They were blessed with a beautiful baby girl and the plan was that she would go back to work when the baby turned one.  Unfortunately, Guillaume was diagnosed with terminal
cancer the day before their first wedding anniversary. Seven months later Guillaume passed away. Guillaume made sure there were life insurance
policies in place, he was always the planner. Seeing the potential success of
Add-a-Handle Tara decided to invest her own savings and take the risk.  We hope that this
makes you feel confident in doing the same!
Our goal is set at $28,000; however, we are confident kind people like yourself will help us to soar way passed that! For the people who are new to Indiegogo, if we do not reach our goal they charge a 9% fee plus credit card processing fees.  If/when we do reach our goal, then there is a 4% charge plus processing fees.  We have taken this into account and chosen to go with a lower financial goal so that there is more money in our pocket later. Always plan
for the worst when it comes to fees!  We
are still waiting on quotes for 1- and 4-cavity molds. Clearly, the less machine time an
injection molder spends on your product, the lower per piece price, and then we can
offer an economic selling price to the buyer.
Once we have the mold made we can then
start production. We have all the suppliers in place and they are ready and
excited about taking what was once an idea through to having a product in your hands! Again, they are all in the USA and we will be using the brand VELCRO® because quality
matters to us! So let’s talk money. The minimum order we can place and have a decent price point is for 5000 units. If 5000 or more Add-a-Handles are redeemed in
PERKs then we will be ecstatic and ready! Please help make this happen. We will definitely know we are doing
something right. Let’s hope that happens, but if not it is ok! Once we have product in our hands we can use them for marketing and sales. We already have small companies that are interested in selling them, but we need funding to get the mold made first.
Thank you for your funding and support, in advance, and if you have any questions, concerns or words of encouragement please contact us!  Come back soon so you can see our future updates and progress. 
LET'S MAKE THIS HAPPEN! Don't forget to "LIKE" us on Facebook!
Merci Beaucoup :)

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

As you have noticed, Add-a-Handle does not have any
batteries, cords or need technological upgrades, so no worries about there being
an electrical issue, because We Have it Handled!  We want to assure everyone that we will keep
you posted with updates here and on our website, www.add-a-handle.com,
throughout the campaign.  If you post
questions we will be sure to get back to you as soon as possible.

With all campaigns there is an element of risk.  At  We Have it
Handled Corp we are able to produce a hand-crafted Add-a-Handle for each PERK
redeemed.  If for some reason the support is not fully there, and we cannot get
the tooling done right away we will still do our best to fulfill our obligations. You won’t let that happen though, right? That is how
committed we are to show our thanks!

story:
The Project

Trash Temple will be co-created in the grassroots artspace Chaosmos_/79Au, Athens. Used golden beer cans of a Greek brand will be collected from the streets in order to provide the base material of large-scale installations: golden hybrids from inorganic to botanical, reptilian and bird-like creatures will occupy the space, build gates and tunnels inspired by Maya architecture, climb up walls until the rooftop …

 

Apart from the practical removal of trash from the streets, the project will raise awareness about waste disposal and serve as a shining example how even problematic issues can be turned into art and beauty. The display of golden hybrids, moreover, makes the community aware that hybridity can be more beautiful than homogeneity and should rather be acknowledged than trying to avoid it. Working creatively with homeless and jobless people for an appropriate fee will also be a great support in the sense of a temporary job and give them the opportunity to be included in creating something positive for their neighbourhood.

 

Philosophy

On a highly philosophical level, the project is inspired by the attempt of the modern writer James Joyce to raise the mundane and every-day-experience on the level of sophisticated art and beauty. In a similar sense, it is inspired by ancient and medieval alchemy which, famously, had the ambition to create gold out of minor elements. As the philosopher and ethnobotanist Terence McKenna suggests, this "quest for gold" is, however, not to be understood literally but metaphorically, as a quest to purify spiritually. Moreover, the concrete forms of the installations are inspired by the temple architecture of the Mayas, who didn't use gold as a means for the economy but solely as a gift to their gods. The golden temple made of trash is, therefore, not a praise of the economy but, to the contrary, a praise of spiritual growth.



The hybrid installations unify whole series of genetic evolution in single creatures, making the audience aware of a general fluidity between species, races and genders. Moreover, these creatures resemble hybrid monsters one can find in the myths and legends around the world. While these myths describe these hybrids as terrible and ugly, their golden colour in our installations re-conceptualizes hybridity as beauty and, thus, unfolds a political dimension that embraces cultural hybridity; something that is intensively felt in this particular community and neighbourhood where people from different cultural and social backgrounds try to coexist.

A third, ecological dimension not only makes the visitors aware of the growing issues of waste disposal, but also serves as an example of how it can be tackled artistically and by the community. This practical perspective eventually refers back to the initial inspiration of the project by James Joyce and alchemy. While these inspirations remain on the individual level of theory, Trash Temple pushes the concept further to collective practice transforming the "lowest" trash into the "highest" treasure and beauty.

 

 

Who we are

Vandaloop collective realizes site-specific, nomadic exhibitions at large-scale extreme spaces, interacting each time with the issues of the local community which is located around those spaces. The collective was founded in 2015 in Berlin.

Our practice is based on interdisciplinary research, re-conceptualizing myth, vertigo, eroticism and mystery in the contemporary urban context. Using beer cans, plastic bags and other artefacts found in the streets, we create post-apocalyptic atmospheres that relate remnants of the past to imagined future potentials or utopias.

 

A project partly funded by a Burning Man Global Art Grant

story:
Welcome to Our project!

 

'What is Alive in You?' is an art-book project that celebrates the beauty of human needs in art and words.  Feelings are beautiful indications of what is needed to live. So to understand your needs is to understand how to live a fulfilling life. We are inspired by Life, nature, non violent communication, and mindfulness, and these concepts find their way into our art and words.   Books will be hand-made in the Catalan countryside (Spain) by independent book makers.

Artwork is done by Aina Oset and writing by Timothy Patey. It is inspired by a need of our times: to understand, recognize, and act upon the human needs that we all need to live a fulfilling life.

Our ethos is to share what is alive in us, to be as vulnerable, honest, and sincere as we can be. By walking this path together and sharing it with the world, we hope to affect positive social change in our changing planet. 

May this book empower you to express what is alive in you and fulfil your beautiful human needs.

 

· Our Team ·

Aina Oset is an artist living near Barcelona, Spain (Social media contact @nalua.lab). Timothy Patey is a scientist, writer, and meditator living in Zürich, Switzerland (Social media contact @awakefulness). The two met at the Nowhere festival (aka the "Burning Man of Europe") in 2016 and have been close friends ever since.

 

· The Impact ·

 

By sponsoring this project, not only will you have a new tool to understand your own needs, but you'll be supporting our mission to improve people's understanding of their own needs. In other words, you'll be sponsoring a self-love activism project, and all the benefits that arise from increased self-awareness.  

On the production side, you will be also supporting a sustainable and ethical small business in Catalunya and their hand made high quality products.

Here you can see some pictures of the printing studio and the process:

 

· What you can get · 

 

A beautiful art & word book on the beauty of human needs.

May this book empower you to express what is alive in you and fulfil your beautiful human needs.

 

A hand-made A5 notebook 

Start your own journey of expressing What is Alive in you in art and words!

 

An A4 print of your choice from any of the artwork from our book

Display it at your home / office / business to remember and enjoy the beauty of human needs

 

· What we need ·

 

5'000 EUR  to complete the financing of our work. This will fund the production of 200 books at a small book publishing business at the Catalonian country-side, digital expenses, shipping costs, the hours the artist & writer invested in this work, and other related expenses. 

 

· Risks & Challenges ·

 

We're doing this, and are self-financing the project if necessary.  For both of us, Aina & Timothy, this is not about making money, but about expressing the beauty of human needs in our own way, and looking back at this "book-making experience" as part of our personal contribution to supporting a more caring and ethical global human community.

We request your help in financing this dream. We hope you will join us on this journey!

 

· Other Ways You Can Help ·

If you're unable to contribute financially, please help make others aware of our project through your newsletters, social media, and word of mouth.  We can be found at the following links:

Indiegogo:  https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/what-is-ali...

Facebook:  https://web.facebook.com/pg/loveisaliveinyou

Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/what_is_alive_in_you/

 

Thank you for your Love and support!
Aina & Tim

 

· Example of work · 

FLOW

 

Breathe in, look, breathe out, act.  

Flow effortlessly aligns our inner state with an outer focus.  We awaken a sleeping expression, a silent aspect of the universe now alive.  Flow is instinctive choice without expectation or explanation. 

We have the capacity to create.  This is bountiful giving to Life. We escape repetitive patterns and join the Gods in their playful dance. These acts are as simple and majestic as dirt: the very stuff of life from which possibilities bloom. The point is Life. Let 'it' happen, be it a step, a prose, a garden, a construct; build it!  Align with the waves as they arrive: birth, dance, art, sex, laughter, death. Wait, they will come.  Be taken, fully, all layers of your being surrendered. Each crisp frame arriving, engaged with hands, belly, body, environment.

When we flow, the poles of our stories resolve; the wreckage of internal contradictions become the earth for our flowers. These ingredients are here, right now, and nothing is missing that would make you more complete. You are 'it', a complete and perfect being of Light.

story:
Short Summary

  • GreenHill is the center for NC art and is the only non-collecting organization dedicated to presenting, promoting and advocating for contemporary visual art and artists of NC.
  • GreenHill offers a wide-range of exhibitions featuring works by contemporary NC artists. Exhibitions are developed to give artists exposure and commercial opportunities.  
  • This exhibition is unique and unexpected and, like everything we do, we need financial support to make it happen. We've already raised preliminary funds to get it started, but still need a boost to help cover some of the additional costs.
  • In supporting M.A.D you support GreenHill and make our dream a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is to raise $24,250 which pays for:
    • Bikes
    • Artist’s site-specific installation
    • Programs
  • Every little bit helps, no matter how big or small.
  • The perks are fun, friendly and exciting
    • $10 - Social Media Shout Out
    • $25 - Exhibition Tickets
    • $50 - Motorcycle T-Shirt 
    • $100 - Downloadable Elemeno Album
    • $250 – Bike Sponsor
    • $500 - Graffiti Sponsor
    • $1,000 - M.A.D Catalogue

The Impact

  • Art takes so many different forms.  The motorcycle is perfect example of great design; the innovation and natural beauty of it, the way it elicits a range of emotions, how it pulls you in and gives you an adrenaline rush.
  • As we expand people’s definition of contemporary art, it is important to celebrate the unexpected. 
  • At GreenHill we believe the motorcycle is art and we want people to celebrate it.

 Risks & Challenges

  • Our biggest challenge is that it is difficult and scary to do something new and unexpected. We're taking a risk by doing this, but we think it’s worthwhile.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Bring your friends to M.A.D!
  • Come to the Leather + Lace party on February 11 (more details at www.GreenHillNC.org/M.A.D)
  • Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

For almost 40 years, Washington Lawyers for the Arts has provided artists with legal services and education. These services are critical to building the business side of their art careers. We are the only legal service program dedicated to the legal issues uniquely impacting artists in Washington.  

WLA's Impact

  • In 2013 and 2014, our legal clinics have provided no-fee direct legal assistance to over 230 low-income artists.    
  • Over the same time period, we've provided legal education services to another 560 people via our workshop and Speaker's Bureau programs.
     
  • In 2014, we doubled the number of artists we served from the previous year. We know, however, that there is still huge unmet need.  In 2015, we'd like to double the number again.

  • The people we serve are better able to handle the legal and business aspects of their careers as artists. We’ve helped musicians negotiate for their song rights, authors reclaim publication rights, and photographers create portrait services to families in transition. Please watch the video above to hear just a few testimonials from artists that have worked with WLA.  

  • We partner with amazing organizations to provide our services. Here's some of the organizations we're teaming in 2015 to continue meeting the legal needs of Washington's artists:

    • ArtsWA (Washington State Arts Commission)
    • Cornish College of the Arts
    • Gay City Arts
    • Mt. Baker Lofts
    • Photographic Center Northwest
    • Seattle Office of Arts & Culture
    • Seattle University School of Law
    • Shoreline-Lake Forest Park Arts Council
    • Tashiro-Kaplan Artist Lofts
    • University of Washington School of Law
    • WSBA Intellectual Property Section

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your support to continue providing our services and grow our reach to more areas of the state. We largely provide our services in King County. Our goal is to meaningfully expand our geographic coverage in the next year to honor our mission of serving Washington artists in all of our counties, but frankly, even our King County services are endangered without financial support. WLA has no endowment, our existence depends on supporters like you.  

  • A gift of any size is hugely helpful, and you have our great and sincere thanks for your financial support. We will recognize our supporters on our website and printed program materials. You will also be provided with a receipt for tax purposes. WLA is a 501(c)(3) organization. 
  • For some gift levels, we are excited and happy to offer "perks" like invitations to come to a clinic, attend an art event with our street team, and party with us at our annual celebration.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Intellectual Property Law can be challenging for an artist to navigate, and we’re here to help. Please share the word about Raising the Bar for Arts, and the programs offered by Washington Lawyers for the Arts!

  • Share this campaign with your networks.
  • Connect with us on Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn.
  • Keep up with our news on our mailing list.
  • Volunteer! We need attorneys to staff phone clinics, accept referrals, and write legal information for our website. 
  • Join a committee. We need volunteers to help with our website and outreach.
  • Come to a workshop.
  • Become a member.
story_txt:
Short Summary
For almost 40 years, Washington Lawyers for
the Arts has provided artists with legal services and education. These services are critical to building the
business side of their art careers. We are the only legal service program dedicated
to the legal issues uniquely impacting artists in Washington.  WLA's Impact

In 2013 and 2014, our legal clinics have provided no-fee direct legal assistance to over 230 low-income artists.    

Over the same time period, we've provided legal education services to another 560 people via our workshop and Speaker's Bureau programs. 

In 2014, we doubled the number of artists we served from the previous year. We know, however, that there is still huge unmet need.  In 2015, we'd like to double the number again.

The people we serve are better able to handle the legal and business aspects of their careers as artists. We’ve helped musicians negotiate for their song rights, authors reclaim publication rights, and photographers create portrait services to families in transition. Please watch the video above to hear just a few testimonials from artists that have worked with WLA.  
We partner with amazing organizations to provide our services. Here's some of the organizations we're teaming in 2015 to continue meeting the legal needs of Washington's artists:


ArtsWA (Washington State Arts Commission)
Cornish College of the Arts
Gay City Arts
Mt. Baker Lofts
Photographic Center Northwest
Seattle Office of Arts & Culture
Seattle University School of Law
Shoreline-Lake Forest Park Arts Council
Tashiro-Kaplan Artist Lofts
University of Washington School of Law
WSBA Intellectual Property Section



What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to meaningfully expand our geographic coverage in the next year to honor our mission of serving Washington artists in all of our counties, but frankly, even our King County services are endangered without financial support. story:
We are a group of Liverpool artists and have been invited to exhibit our work at the platform project at Art Athena Contemporary art exhibition in Athens and would like at least three artists to attend. We've been working hard producing original artwork for sale to contribute to this campaign which will enable us to show our artwork in Athens. Your contribution would help us raise funds towards airfare, accommodation, and shipping costs. Ultimately your help will allow us to show our work on an international level as well as being there to represent the group. This also gives us the opportunity to help other artists as we can making connections and opening doors for future collaborations.

Help us to show amazing artworks across the Atlantic and be rewarded by receiving original artwork in return!!

You can find more details about the project and artists by looking at our artists website, found here.

What You Get

As well as a massive thank-you from us for helping funding the project, We also have several exciting rewards available to you. These range from receiving signed limited edition prints to wonderful original artworks!

Here are images of the artworks you can receive...

From £10... 

This A5 mixed media paper collage 'Tube Map', by Wendy Williams could be yours for this £10 perk! 

This A5 original collage artwork 'Untitled' by Hilal Ozelci could be yours for this £10 perk!

A selection of A5 oil on paper works based on 'Star Wars' by Elizabeth Wheeler. Each of these 5 original artworks are £10. Please let us know which one you would like by checking out the selection here.  Star wars (3), Star wars (4), Star wars (5) have been sold! 2 still available! 

An A5 original paper collage 'L'essence Parfumée: Intense' artwork by Michael Borkowsky will be yours for this £10 perk.

An A5 original paper collage 'L'essence Parfumée: Coastal' artwork by Michael Borkowsky will be yours for this £10 perk.

We also have a number of SCI original art works for sale at £10 here. To purchase choose the 'Original Artwork by SCI' perk and comment or send us an email at soupliverpool@yahoo.co.uk to let us know which one you have purchased. 


From £12...


This small had printed drawstring bag by Sufea Mohammod Noor could be yours for this £12 perk!

From £15...

An A5 acrylic painting by Jackie Kerr 'Escape' could be yours for the £15 perk!

An A3 digital print 'Ruins' by Sumuyya Khader could be yours for this £15 perk! 

 '

Untitled' Fibre-based silver gelatin print by Sophie Neilson. This 5x12inches work can be yours for this £15 perk!

'Lines' an A5 original watercolour by Ruth Morrissey could be yours for this £15 perk. 

From £20...

An original A4 drawing 'View' by Sumuyya Khader could be yours for this £20 perk!  

A 30x30cm Limited edition 'Infinity' print by Catherine Harrison will be yours for this £20 perk. The prints are limited edition and are signed by the artist. 

'Feathers' An A2 etching by Janet Wilkinson could be yours for this £20 perk.  

From £25

 
An A1 Stencil on paper print 'The Void' by Keiron Finnetty will be yours for this £25 perk. These prints are a limited edition of 10 and will be signed by the artist.

An A4 print of Michael Borkowsky's painting 'Brain in a Bottle' will be yours for this £25 perk. The print will is a limited edition of 20 and will be signed by the artist. 

£30 +

'Dislocated Series' an A5 collage on paper by Maria Christoforatou. This original artwork can be yours for this £30 Perk!

'12.37.15' A 111x82 cm original drawing mounted on MDF by Sumuyya Khader could be yours for this £70 perk. 

'There is another Sky' Ceramics, Paper and Mesh by Wendy Williams. This 30x30cm framed original artwork could be yours for this £100 perk!  

'Hermes Trismegistus' Pen and ink on paper(unframed). This 18x18inches original artwork can be yours for this £200 perk!   

What We Need 

We are seeking your support to cover part of the traveling costs, exhibition fees, shipping and art handling. £750 of our total funds will allow us to fund three members of SCI to represent us, take the work and set up the exhibition at Art Athena. 

The Impact

Any contribution will make a difference!

We will be taking a number of work on behalf of our group, that way more artists will benefit from my participation in this exhibition. This way we are creating an opportunity for other artists and whilst the representatives are there they will be creating possible professional relationships, exhibitions and exchanges for our artists group. We will be meeting artists from all over the world, art gallery directors, cultural institutions, curators, collectors and art critics, attending schedule of lectures throughout the event, getting professional advise, and making connections. We would be speaking to artists about possible exhibition and studio exchanges as well to offer the chance to others to do the same.

Other Ways You Can Help

Regardless of whether you can donate money, it'd be very much appreciated if you could spread the word and share our project with people you know. Please use the share tools to promote this campaign on your social media! You can find more details by looking at the SCI page on my website, found here. Also if you have any questions or would like to get in touch email us at soupliverpool@yahoo.co.uk

Please, support us in any way you can and spread the word!

Thank you!

story:
Miles to Go

The title for this campaign is based on the Robert Frost poem Stopping by the Woods on a Snowy Evening. This is the last stanza:

It's a classic poem and most kids in the US study this poem at some point in school. It's about obligations, responsibilities, and completing work before relaxing and "calling it a day". I will literally have many, many, many miles to go. It will be challenging work, but the reward is that there will be so much beauty (photos, paintings, recordings) to show for it.

I am a professional artist as well as an avid cyclist. I love the various challenges of both.  When I first began to think of this expedition, I was watching the Tour de France and I was mostly interested in simply getting out of Philadelphia but I quickly realized that what I was really anticipating was hearing sounds in isolation. I love solitude and what I really wanted was to listen to those open spaces between me and Marfa, TX. I want to make new work about those sounds and all that space. Most of my art work to date has been paintings, sculptures and site-specific works. Recently, most of my paintings have used aerial photography as a starting point. Sound work is a new genre for me but I welcome the challenge here, too.

I'll use the photos and sketches as source materials for paintings, prints, and so on, but I'm most excited about creating a sound pieces and soundscapes from the best of the ambient sounds that I record. Though those sounds will be of particular places (rivers, open road, isolated city sounds, the sound of flocks of birds migrating, or the sound of rain on dry land), I want to make these sounds even more evocative for the listener by adding images and brief narratives about the sounds. My plan is to take aerial photos of each of the locations where I document sounds in order to achieve the balance between specificity and open-endedness that I'm looking for. Essentially, I want to evoke specific places while also leaving the viewer/listener room for their own interpretation.

Why Marfa?

Marfa is a vibrant little arts town out in the middle of nowhere, down close to the border of Texas and Mexico. One of my closest friends lives there so it's an ideal destination for a project that is based on distance, isolation and solitude. I've never been there and I'm so excited about this as my destination.

Logistics

This trip is slightly more than 2200 miles from Philadelphia to Marfa. My goal is to bike 80-100 miles each day. Currently, I cycle 25-30 miles a day, so committing to one month of longer rides is not too far fetched for me. I'm planning on making this trip alone in September because the weather is relatively mild then. It's also my birthday month and this seems like the very best way to celebrate life and big, big horizons.

I will not be camping, but staying in roadside motels. I will fly back to Philadelphia at the end of the trip. I have made arrangements for friends to send "drops" of supplies to a few locations along the way, which will limit the weight and amount of supplies that I'll have to pack on my bike.

I have a Surly Long Haul Trucker bike that I bought specifically for this trip. I'll have 2+ panniers on the bike. For the record, I've named my bike Sally Ride, in honor of the first female astronaut from the US.

What I'll Be Doing

I'm biking 2200+ miles by myself, which is a big feat on it's own. Along the way, I'll be documenting the trip through photos (by land and by drone), sketches and sound recordings. This documentation will be used in completed paintings, prints and a "white noise" piece that will utilize 10+ of my favorite sounds from the trip along with images and accompanying text. 

What I Need

Where the money will go:

  • $2100- travel expenses (motels along the way. This is calculated at $70/night x 30 nights. I am not attempting to stay in 4-star hotels, nor am I interested in camping. $70 is budget motel rate).
  • $950- equipment for the trip (drone, recording equipment, rain gear, emergency gear, solar charger)
  • $600-food and miscellaneous expenses.
  • $450- return flight (I don't want to ride back...)
  • $1600- production costs (printing, t-shirts, water bottles, wristbands, programming).

Any additional funds raised during this campaign will go towards creating a "white noise" app that would incorporate longer sound recordings from this trip along with the corresponding visuals and citations about where, when and why I chose those sounds.

What You'll Get

Obviously, you'll get my gratitude but I've put together what I think is a great array of awesomeness that suits budgets of any size. I'll also keep everyone updated on the blog and social media so you can keep track of my training, prep, challenges and thrills along the way.

The perks range from screensavers and ringtones to limited prints and original artwork.

Why This is Important

Well, in short, I think it's important to do "crazy" things at times. It's easy to get complacent in life and I want to make sure that I keep challenging myself physically and artistically. I believe strongly that my work is important and should be supported widely. Below is a small selection of my work:

Risks & Challenges

Personal Safety: Being out by myself is a risk, but I've been training and I won't be taking unnecessary risks.

  • To this end, I won't be camping.
  • I will be taking personal safety classes before the trip.

There is no significant risk to the project being completed and in a timely manner. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are on social media, I would really appreciate sharing this campaign with your networks. Tell your friends. Tell your family. Tell your local bike shops. Tell everyone. The earlier the support, the better because it helps to attract more attention for the project.

Thanks for all of your help! This is going to be amazing!

story:
Typically, fundraising efforts articulate the What, Who, Why of a project. Yet this project is not common, so these questions will be addressed in uncommon fashion.

WHAT: Financial support is needed in the amount of $999  to complete a visual-linguistic contribution to the neural network of humankind. This creative expression is comprised of some hundred-twenty existing slides that need to be converted into another format and made freely available online.

WHO: This is an uncredited project. It is neither created nor offered to call attention to the one through whom the work comes into being. 

WHY: Creativity is the wisdom-display of intelligence. Why is anything created; why is any articulation expressed? Are those who produce street art non-contributive? Acknowledging what is cannot be reduced to a business objective. Just as the impetus for this fundraise is derived from a so-called vision quest, the initiative for this project is derived from stillness.  The arrow knows not the purpose or target of its flight. 

While artist/author and audience are equally unspecified, what can be clarified is that prior to a “theft” of some 4,500 dollars, funding for the completion of the project was in hand. This inconvenience renders one as vulnerable as to beg on the streets to make ends meet. Such vulnerability appreciates kindness.

False promises and hopes are easily sold in a world turned toward megalomania and shopping malls. The return offered here is that once the project is completed (spring 2019), funders will receive a link to the online project, in addition to deep gratitude. 

The first few slides are shared below. With appreciation and comp-passion, - c

story:
After four years working to transform the fortunes of a failing Jazz Cafe, The Verdict is now thriving as a cafe and the Jazz club is rated as one of the top five venues for Jazz in Europe. 

I would like to start something new, something different that both challenges and rewards my creative and social interests and provides a much needed facility in Brighton.

“Speakers Corner”

A high quality coffee shop and multidisciplinary creative space, ‘Speakers Corner’ aims to provide far more than just great food, divine coffees and a warm welcome, although this will remain a cornerstone of our local community-focussed business.  

Concept and business streams

With generous local support from designers, architects, solicitors and specialist tradespeople, we plan to transform a dormant Brighton Kemptown retail unit into a vibrant location that will offer a range of exciting facilities and opportunities for visual artists, poets, musicians, sound artists and photographers alike. 

Key to our concept will be a highly adaptable environment in which all furniture and fixings are designed to be easily moved, on locking-castors, into a range of different configurations to enable the space to be used as a gallery, performance venue, teaching and seminar area, debating chamber, film and audio-visual room and, significantly, an environment where people can listen to music on a hi-fi system that delivers an unprecedented level of sonic quality. Our aim is to have the best sound system in town, where people can convene to fully appreciate the richness of recordings of all genres and eras.

 

The Cafe: We will continue to provide wonderful food from breakfast to mid afternoon, creating evolving menus that emphasise regionality, partnerships with local suppliers and the highest quality seasonal produce. This, combined with specialist coffee and teas, is something we understand and do well. Furthermore, we have built a strong and loyal customer base who want to follow our team the the new location, a mere twenty metres away.

‘Speakers Corner’:  A play on words, Speakers Corner will in the first instance be a place of free expression, dialogue, discussion and meaningful conversation. Beyond the day to day human interactions, we will be running or hosting a range of events, talks and meet-ups in the cafe.  

The second meaning behind our name reveals our plan to launch one of the countries first ‘Listening Clubs’, a place to hear music, calmly and with a new clarity and depth and quality. We’ve chosen to re-build a 'horn & tube’ pairing of vintage speakers from the golden era of speaker production that will be driven by a vacuum valve amplifier. In tests, listeners are astonished by the natural sound such systems reproduce, remarking that they sound just like real acoustic instruments. Violins sounds so real, and never screechy. Piano sounds like piano, vocals sound real, and holographic. Macro and micro transient dynamic resolution detail is startling. You can hear the breath of a singers voice, the stick hit on the skin of drums, the crack of the snare, and the reverb and decay of the sound. The bottom end sounds clear and detailed, lots of resolution, its visceral,  YOU FEEL IT!

The Gallery: With two unbroken walls, we have a perfect space for showing fine art, photography, illustration and other visual arts. In partnership with specialist curators and directly with artists, we are building a programme of exhibitions both in support of local artists and to show work by respected international artists for the year ahead.

Education/Artist support: In collaboration with Brighton’s two universities, music colleges as well as through independent initiatives of our own, ‘Speakers Corner’ will have a role in encouraging the development of young and not-so-young artists alike.  Through talks and seminars, guest speakers, folio sessions and film screenings, not to mention the use of wall-space, and the unique opportunity to fully appreciate music and sound arts projects, ‘Speakers Corner’ will be equipped with high speed broadband internet, a standardised gallery lighting system, a full HD projection facilities and, of courses, a very special sound system in order to deliver on all these fronts and more.

Our community: This is without doubt the most important piece of the exciting jigsaw. The positive role played by Speakers Corner within our immediate community is fundamental to our future plans. We aim to achieve this in a number of ways: First, Speakers Corner will be staffed by people from the area. In conjunction with a customer incentive scheme, we want all our waste to go to good causes. To this end we plan to encourage our customers to donate a small sum with their order in order to allow us to turn any produce we are left with at the end of the day into meals for those in need. This food will be donated to the local homeless and unemployed centre. Once weekly, Speakers corner will be made available, free of charge, to community-based initiatives at the end of the working day. A place to meet, discuss, demonstrate crafts, share skills or just to support each other, we want Speakers Corner to be seen as a ‘people’s space’, without judgement, prejudice or fear.

 

The team

John Easterby: Owner

After a long and successful career in photography and Higher Education, John took over a failing cafe /club called The Verdict in the same neighbourhood that he now plans to open Speakers Corner. It was the realisation of a life-long ambition to work in a culinary, people-led environment. Year on year for the last four years, business has more than doubled, and he and his team have built great reputation in a vibrant community that includes the European American Express Headquarters, Brighton University, the Law Courts and many local residents. 

"For over thirty years I was lucky to work at a very high level within the international world of documentary and reportage photography, starting my career with Magnum Photos in London as part of Neil Burgess' team in the mid 80s. I was then given the opportunity by Geoff Katz to start a new specialist photo-agency, which we named Independent Photographers Group. Through the remarkable work of such photographers as Tom Stoddart, David Modell, Alastair Thain and Zed Nelson, to name but a few, the IPG name became synonymous with photography of the highest quality, with work by our photographers dominating the most important international awards for close to a decade. Both in these jobs and later as course director for the MA Photojournalism & Documentary Photography at London College of Communication, I saw my role as one in which I helped photographers to reach their potential. In particular during my time at LCC, it was incredibly rewarding for me to see the improvement in students work after we had worked together, and more rewarding still to have followed the careers and growth of so many of these talented individuals.

I have found genuine happiness and contentment in my new life but also realise that I still have a lot to offer photographers who want to improve and evolve. At Speakers Corner, I will combine the old with the new by introducing a series of lectures, discussions and folio sessions designed to help photographers develop and see the world and the human condition more acutely. I also plan to start a series of public (rather than purely photographers) talks and assignment briefings, designed to help people learn to look at the world around them with a more critical eye.  

It's really exciting to be planning future in which my past and my present interests converge."

Natasha Thoday: Sound. 

Natasha began designing and building vacuum tube electronic amplifier and horn loaded loudspeakers in the 1990s, following a life long passion for music and audio equipment. Whilst working as an audio retail consultant, she researched analogue acoustic science and technology history, going on to build a number of bespoke or prototype horn loudspeakers, tube amplifiers and record players. For example, she project managed the redesign and hand assembly of CNC manufactured parts for the Audio Note Japan Io phono cartridge, a high end global distributed model for vinyl L.P. record replay. She has also designed, prototyped, batch produced and sold a novel patented tone arm for replaying vinyl L.P.'s using a spring rather than the usual counterweight.

Patrick Turner-Lee: Artistic advisor

Fine artist, poet and musician, Patrick Turner-Lee has been instrumental in helping John transform his previous business, The Verdict Cafe, from a ‘one trick pony’ Jazz venue into one that has become relevant and respected within many new fields of art and performance.  

“ One of the most frustrating things I have discovered about living in Brighton is the chronic shortage of venues where like-minded creative people can meet to discus their ideas and have their project needs supported. I work with many groups in Brighton including acting classes, poetry reading and writing groups, and we struggle to find suitable spaces to convene and share.

The proposal for Speakers Corner identifies and will satisfy a real need in this city.  It will be a significant contribution to the local community and there are many groups who would benefit from an environment that is not only actively supporting exhibitions and events but enabling the consistent and sustainable development of cultural exchange on many exciting and effective levels.

I have seen how John encourages and stimulates artists of all ages and have no doubt that Speakers Corner will not only be a wonderful community cafe, but also an important space for self expression and the development of ideas. I am really excited to be involved in a venue with an outstanding atmosphere built on a deep respect for the creative freedom of the individual.”

The Ask

With pledges of help-in-kind from local solicitors, designers, architects and tradespeople, not to mention a huge response from the local community, it is my hope that the collective experience of making this project happen will lay the foundations for a lasting connection with our friends and partners in the area. The process of transformation will be documented, collated and preserved as a lasting record.

Despite the many offers of help, there will be significant costs associated with refitting the shop and creating a beautiful environment. We need to install a kitchen, wet area, public toilet and service counter. We need to build the sound system. Then there is the lighting, furniture, and refrigeration. In short, in order to get the space up and ready to run for a launch in July, I'd like to raise  £15,000.

The costs fall into two main categories, A: behind the counter and B: the shop floor

A: Dishwasher:............................................................800
    Fridges/Freezer x 3:...............................................700
    Extractor & ducting:..............................................1000
    Stainless-steel work tables & shelves: .................500
    Chilled display unit: ...............................................1500
    Counter build:........................................................2500
     
Estimated costs of category A: ............................£7000

B: Painting/tiling and decorating:...........................1000
     Soft seating area:...................................................500
     Castor system for tables:....................................1000    
     Sound system:.....................................................4000
     Lighting:...................................................................700
     HD projector:.........................................................1000

Estimated costs of category B:..............................£8000

I would like to raise as much of this money as possible through a crowd funding campaign, lasting six weeks. This will be done in parallel with a number of other fund raising events, in many cases made possible be the kindness of musicians and artists who have offered their time and talent for free.

Friends, I really need your help.

The Reward Ladder

All donors will be acknowledged by name of our 'Wall of Friends' plaque, permanently on display in Speakers Corner.

1: Platinum level sponsor, for donations over £2000, may wish to specify which area of the business they would like their support to be directed. For example 'The Kitchen was made possible by kindness Mr Parker".

Platinum level sponsors will enjoy:-

  • Free entry to all events in perpetuity.
  • Free use of the venue for one private event a year, in perpetuity.
  • Free coffee and soft drinks for two years.

2: Gold level sponsor, for donations over £1000, may also wish to specify which of the areas they would like to direct their support,

and will enjoy:-

  • Free entry to all events, for one year from the date of the opening party.
  • Free use of the venue for one private event per year, for the first two years after opening party.
  • Free daily coffee for one year after opening (Value of £648, based on one coffee per working day)

3: Silver level sponsor, for donation over £500, may wish to specify which area of the business they would like their support to be directed,

and will enjoy:-

  • Free entry to all events, for six months after the opening party.
  • Free use of the venue for one private event at any time during first year.
  • Free coffee for six months after opening.

4: Bronze level sponsor, for donations over £100

will enjoy:-

  • Free entry to five events over first year, after the opening party.
  • Five free soups, five free sandwiches or salads and five free coffees/teas, to be taken in any denomination at any time over first year.

5: Entry level sponsor donations over £10

will enjoy:-

  • Free entry to one event during first year, from date of opening party.
  • One free lunch or the equivalent of Coffee/tea, Soup, Sandwich or Salad.

 

The Speakers Corner advance purchase bond

Many existing customers of ours at The Verdict Café have stated that they will follow me, my team and our menu too the new location, just around the corner. In order to generate as much desperately needed working capital as possible, supporters are invited to buy their food and drinks in advance. In return for this support we will increase the value of this advances purchase by 15%.

So, for example, if you invest £100 against future purchases, we will increase the value of your investment to £115. All future sales will be debited from your account, until the full figure is spent.

Please let us know in advance that you are supporting the project in this way.

Finally, in recognition of everyone's different circumstances and in gratitude to all of you who have chosen to support my project; every donor, irrespective of how much you could donate, will be invited to our opening party later this summer. It'll be a good night!

Thank you!

John

After four years working to transform the fortunes of a failing Jazz Cafe, The Verdict is now thriving as a cafe and the Jazz club is rated as one of the top five venues for Jazz in Europe. I would like to start something new, something different that both challenges and rewards my creative and social interests and provides a much needed facility in Brighton.“Speakers Corner”A high quality coffee shop and multidisciplinary creative space, ‘Speakers Corner’ aims to provide far more than just great food, divine coffees and a warm welcome, although this will remain a cornerstone of our local community-focussed business.  Concept and business streamsWith generous local support from designers, architects, solicitors and specialist tradespeople, we plan to transform a dormant Brighton Kemptown retail unit into a vibrant location that will offer a range of exciting facilities and opportunities for visual artists, poets, musicians, sound artists and photographers alike. Key to our concept will be a highly adaptable environment in which all furniture and fixings are designed to be easily moved, on locking-castors, into a range of different configurations to enable the space to be used as a gallery, performance venue, teaching and seminar area, debating chamber, film and audio-visual room and, significantly, an environment where people can listen to music on a hi-fi system that delivers an unprecedented level of sonic quality. Our aim is to have the best sound system in town, where people can convene to fully appreciate the richness of recordings of all genres and eras. The Cafe: We will continue to provide wonderful food from breakfast to mid afternoon, creating evolving menus that emphasise regionality, partnerships with local suppliers and the highest quality seasonal produce. This, combined with specialist coffee and teas, is something we understand and do well. Furthermore, we have built a strong and loyal customer base who want to follow our team the the new location, a mere twenty metres away.‘Speakers Corner’:  A play on words, Speakers Corner will in the first instance be a place of free expression, dialogue, discussion and meaningful conversation. Beyond the day to day human interactions, we will be running or hosting a range of events, talks and meet-ups in the cafe.  The second meaning behind our name reveals our plan to launch one of the countries first ‘Listening Clubs’, a place to hear music, calmly and with a new clarity and depth and quality. We’ve chosen to re-build a 'horn & tube’ pairing of vintage speakers from the golden era of speaker production that will be driven by a vacuum valve amplifier. In tests, listeners are astonished by the natural sound such systems reproduce, remarking that they sound just like real acoustic instruments. Violins sounds so real, and never screechy. Piano sounds like piano, vocals sound real, and holographic. Macro and micro transient dynamic resolution detail is startling. story:
*** Stretch goal: $15,000: Chrome plate the dragon. *** With this extra $4000 we will have the dragon chrome plated. The dragon will take on a brilliant, shining, scratch-resistant finish, blindingly bright, and be forever known as "that incredibly shiny, chromed-out dragon." If it comes under budget, we will complement the chrome exterior with spinning rims.  

*** Stretch goal: $11,000: Sandblast and seal the dragon. Complete! *** We are floored and incredibly grateful to report we have reached 102% of our goal! Thank you to everybody who has donated. Our first stretch goal is $11,000. With this extra $1000 we will have the dragon professionally sand blasted and sealed with epoxy to restore its original shine and remove the rust that has built up over the last 14 months. 

One Year, 20 Events, Toward a Ten Art Car Toronto

Heavy Meta is a 30 foot-long metal dragon mutant vehicle, the largest of its kind in Canada. Last year, over 100 volunteers worked to bring it to life in some way or another, a group ranging from high school students to marine engineers learning and teaching metalwork, flame effects design, carpentry, and how to fully embrace the "get stuff done" attitude. The beast has three massive flame effects, a moving jaw, and can play host to a multitude of performers from DJs to chain aerial acrobats.



Huge Needs for This Summer

  • Fuel to and from Burning Man ($3000)
  • New generator ($3000)
  • Finish lighting system ($1000)
  • Finish articulating wings ($1000)
  • General repairs ($1000)
  • Shop expenses ($1000)  

Where is my money going?

Heavy Meta has done a lot with very little over the past year, and its volunteers have worked tirelessly installing the dragon at events around the northeast. We have also thrown a number of fundraiser parties, including our successful Metaverse event with The Ark Car, where we raised a good amount toward our fuel to and from Burning Man. However, we have a lot to power: the dragon itself is about 10,000 lbs. of steel and vehicle driving up and down mountains to the desert from Toronto. The companion bus that moves our early arrival campers to Burning Man also needs enough gas to move 10 volunteers the same distance.

 

Night Lighting System

We have a confession to make: Last year at Burning Man, the dragon looked a bit like an amorphous rainbow blob from a distance. This was not the intended effect! This year, we have already created 26 wood-and-acrylic panels that will glow brilliantly at the burn. We just need a little more help getting the proper LED strips, power supplies, and controllers, and the dragon's luminous skeleton will shine brightly from event great distances. 

Articulating Wings

Before Lakes of Fire this year, Matt Von Wilde pulled off a heroic effort to construct all-new aluminum wings that open and close with the turn of a winch. With some more work (and aluminum), we will be able to have them open 90º off the sides of the bus, completing our vision of a 38-foot span from wingtip to wingtip. 

The Generator 

We have another confession to make: we really cheaped out on a generator to power our sound gear, air compressor, fire system, propane tank warming system, and lights last year. It was intended to be a stopgap solution, and the old adage about "getting what you pay for" is true. Our generator is on its last legs and must be upgraded if we are to survive Burning Man this year. 

The 4tress: Hub for A Community

The 4tress is our 2000 sqft. shop at Dupont and Ossington in Toronto. It is home to several artist groups: The Ark Car (mutant vehicle), Lumatronic (CNC cutting, audiovisual rentals), laser cutters, metalworkers, and carpenters. It is a community asset that has few peers in Toronto: truly a space where artists can dream and make massive art. We have also hosted a series of popular welding classes to help others learn how to turn their vision into steel reality. 

The Dragon's Lair (aka About the 2018 Team)

Kevin Bracken, Cat herder-in-chief: Kevin has a lengthy portfolio of creating huge, outrageous projects, driven in no small part by his love for his adopted city, Toronto.  

Marie Poliak, Chief designer: Marie Poliak is an artist who enjoys all things shiny. Co-owner of a satirical fashion label, mother of dragons, and all around sweetie pie. Marie enjoys long walks on the moon while casually plotting a path to global domination. 

Matt Von Wilde, Generalissimo: Matt is the head honcho of house music collective Secret Society, as well as being a badass carpenter and metalworker.  

Stacy Campbell, Fire Lead: A member of I.A.T.S.E Local 873, Stacy specializes in special effects and makeup artistry, as well as a core member of our flame effects team.

Christiane Yerex, Fire Maiden: Christiane has been there since the beginning, a true ride-or-die badgyal. 

Ben Cormier, The Man: Ben is the man, also an explosively talented resident DJ.

Alex Borins, heir to the welding mask: Alex's incredible ability to learn is matched only by his inexhaustible energy. Fixes everything from bikes to soundsystems using only a hairdryer.  

Patrick Vipond, Chief welder: Patrick is Heavy Meta's deus ex machina, off-roading enthusiast and welder. 

Nikki Sin, Media Team: Nikki is nearly every event on the road, tirelessly documenting and hyping the dragon. 

Alex Gold, Behind the scenes: Alex's city-A.D.H.D. is unparalleled and if he could just figure out where the hell he lives, maybe he'd have more time to work on the damn dragon. 

Jesse Champagne, Resident DJ: Jesse may be one of those "wear black while spinning minimal" types, but we love him all the same.

Alex Lebedev, electronics: Alex has been there through thick and thin, making stuff work and bringing his unique know-how to difficult problems.

Jamie Chebodiac, viking: Jamie comes to nearly every event on the road, while not busy appearing on made-in-Toronto TV shows like The Expanse and Killjoys. 

Ellis Briery, Assistant welder: Ellis is the resident cat/mascot, also pretty handy with engines and power tools. Prodigal Swan Alum

Special thanks to the dragon family: Dani Cullimore, Petro Vesna, Site 3 Fire Arts, Dustin T. Hoffman, Austin Simpson, Chris Polley, Nikki Sin, Travis Johnson, Lolita Devlin, Olivia Coombe, Alina Dee, Dian Carlo, Geordie, Lindsay Millard, Priya Sarin, Jordan Snyder, Oz Carroll, Caspar Cash, Simon Plashkes, Mikale Pilgrim, Tiphane Leonard, Pavel Tchourliaev, Brian Dunseith, Miruna Toma, David Fradkin, Matt Languay, Patrick Brambley, Dasha Pyat, Patrick Leckie, Ryan Smythe, Laura Brien, Emma Duggan, Ben Retan, Andrea Shehara, Jacqueline Fernandez, Tamara Moskaliuk, Jay Ould, Christine Irving, Mell Barry, Sam Jarvis, Darryn Coleman, Jesse Champagne, Marina Izvekova, Ryan Wemyss, Maaor Ziv, Tim Sandik, Darcy Holt, Brittany Wharton, Sofia Timkovski, Dustin Nantais, Air`leth Aodhfin, Mike Dineen, JELO, George Hatiras, Robb G, Stephan Larose, Thomas Cardin, and Kevin's mom. 

Perks 

$5 - High Five
This is like you giving us a high five - thanks!

$10 - A Thank You Digital Postcard from The Artists
Our heartfelt gratitude, and a personalized digital photo postcard of the dragon at Burning Man.

$20 - Dine in Valhalla (VIP ticket to the Burning Man Farewell Party)
This ticket grants you VIP admission to the dragon itself at the next Metaverse party - mid-August date. 


$20 - Heavy Meta Sticker
A die-cut, high-quality Heavy Meta sticker for your car, laptop, mutant vehicle, tiny home, RV, flamethrower, etc. 

$40 - Dragon Rider acrylic pendant 
CNC-cut, 1/4"-thick acrylic Heavy Meta text logo pendant.

$60 - Heavy Meta Shirt
Printed in North America on 100% cotton tee. White on black, unisex sizes S - XXL.



$60 - Heavy Meta Tank Top
Printed in North America on 100% cotton tee. White on black, unisex sizes S - XXL.

$100 - Dragon Rider steel pendant
CNC plasma cut 1/4"-thick steel Heavy Meta logo pendant.

$300 - One-of-a-Kind Watercolor by Marie Poliak
Marie will paint you a one-of-a-kind 6" x 8" watercolor of Heavy Meta, one-person portrait, a couple's portrait, or a pet.  

$500 - DJ Set on the dragon
Are you ready to drop some sick beats on the playa? Spin whatever you want on our 10,000-watt soundsystem for 2 hours. 

$500 - Hand-hammered steel helmet
Matt Von Wilde will hand-hammer you a steel helmet in the Spartan Wraith or Spartan Warrior style. Comes with weathered, pitted, battle-blemished finish. Your tinfoil hat is now obsolete.



Above: Actual helmets made by Matt 

$1,000 - Customize our license plate
Choose our license plate, up to 8 characters, to say anything you want! We would like it to say HVYMETA but you might want it to say SAMRULEZ or something. (We reserve the right to veto hateful phrases.) 

$3,750 - Party anywhere in Ontario
We will bring Heavy Meta to your festival, concert, bar mitzvah, children's birthday party, raids on an enemy kingdom, grandparents' wedding anniversary, and more! Comes complete with soundsystem, flame effects, lighting effects, trained operators, and DJs if requested. Available anywhere in Ontario. 

$8,000 - Party anywhere in North America
We will bring Heavy Meta to your festival, concert, bar mitzvah, children's birthday party, quinceañera, grandparents' wedding anniversary, and more! Comes complete with soundsystem, flame effects, lighting effects, trained operators, and DJs if requested. Available in the 48 continental United States and Canada below the arctic circle.  

Frequently Asked Questions

Is this vehicle street legal? 

Yes! Everything you see in the photos is removable, and is able to be stored inside or on top of the bus. During transport, Heavy Meta will simply look like a black school bus with things strapped to the roof, and measure 11.5' high, well below the legal maximum height of 13.5'.   

How do you get it to events, including Burning Man?

We  drive it; it's a bus!

I don't have money to contribute, how else can I help?

We are always looking for volunteers to help us in the shop, which is located near Dupont & Ossington in Toronto. We also need people to share this campaign! Please e-mail hello@heavymeta.ca to get involved.

What happens if you don't raise $10,000? 

So far we have funded this project with the help of personal money, private donors, grants from Great Lakes Experimental Arts and BurnT, and fundraiser parties. We have enough to limp by for another burn, and Heavy Meta will get to Burning Man no matter what, but the full vision is simply not be possible without reaching this goal.

What is the artistic message behind Heavy Meta?

Heavy Meta is the physical manifestation of The Leviathan, the Hobbesian concept of an all-powerful sovereign that rules over a land in order to prevent its subjects from living a life that is “solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short.” Heavy Meta captures the creeping sense of dystopianism that has come to dominate western democracy, and the slouch toward the despots of an age long-past.

However, it is also a symbol of hope: armed with our own dragon, we can liberate a space for ourselves, and create what Hakim Bey called the “Temporary Autonomous Zone,” where we may express our own desires and principles in a land we control with the help of our dragon. The name is a punny, self-referential take on an object that is literally a “heavy metal dragon,” as well as a nod to the 1981 Canadian film Heavy Metal, particularly the final story, where the amazon Taarna, the last surviving member of a warrior race sworn to uphold justice, avenges the evil slaughter of a civilization of philosophers.
story_txt:
*** Stretch goal: $15,000: Chrome plate the dragon. *** With this extra $4000 we will have the dragon chrome plated. The dragon will take on a brilliant, shining, scratch-resistant finish, blindingly bright, and be forever known as "that incredibly shiny, chromed-out dragon." If it comes under budget, we will complement the chrome exterior with spinning rims.  *** Stretch goal: $11,000: Sandblast and seal the dragon. Complete! *** We are floored and incredibly grateful to report we have reached 102% of our goal! Thank you to everybody who has donated. Our first stretch goal is $11,000. With this extra $1000 we will have the dragon professionally sand blasted and sealed with epoxy to restore its original shine and remove the rust that has built up over the last 14 months. One Year, 20 Events, Toward a Ten Art Car TorontoHeavy Meta is a 30 foot-long metal dragon mutant vehicle, the largest of its kind in Canada. Last year, over 100 volunteers worked to bring it to life in some way or another, a group ranging from high school students to marine engineers learning and teaching metalwork, flame effects design, carpentry, and how to fully embrace the "get stuff done" attitude. The beast has three massive flame effects, a moving jaw, and can play host to a multitude of performers from DJs to chain aerial acrobats.Huge Needs for This Summer
Fuel to and from Burning Man ($3000)
New generator ($3000)
Finish lighting system ($1000)
Finish articulating wings ($1000)
General repairs ($1000)
Shop expenses ($1000)  
Where is my money going?Heavy Meta has done a lot with very little over the past year, and its volunteers have worked tirelessly installing the dragon at events around the northeast. We have also thrown a number of fundraiser parties, including our successful Metaverse event with The Ark Car, where we raised a good amount toward our fuel to and from Burning Man. However, we have a lot to power: the dragon itself is about 10,000 lbs. of steel and vehicle driving up and down mountains to the desert from Toronto. The companion bus that moves our early arrival campers to Burning Man also needs enough gas to move 10 volunteers the same distance. Night Lighting SystemWe have a confession to make: Last year at Burning Man, the dragon looked a bit like an amorphous rainbow blob from a distance. This was not the intended effect! This year, we have already created 26 wood-and-acrylic panels that will glow brilliantly at the burn. We just need a little more help getting the proper LED strips, power supplies, and controllers, and the dragon's luminous skeleton will shine brightly from event great distances. Articulating WingsBefore Lakes of Fire this year, Matt Von Wilde pulled off a heroic effort to construct all-new aluminum wings that open and close with the turn of a winch. With some more work (and aluminum), we will be able to have them open 90º off the sides of the bus, completing our vision of a 38-foot span from wingtip to wingtip. The Generator We have another confession to make: we really cheaped out on a generator to power our sound gear, air compressor, fire system, propane tank warming system, and lights last year. It was intended to be a stopgap solution, and the old adage about "getting what you pay for" is true. Our generator is on its last legs and must be upgraded if we are to survive Burning Man this year. The 4tress: Hub for A CommunityThe 4tress is our 2000 sqft. shop at Dupont and Ossington in Toronto. It is home to several artist groups: The Ark Car (mutant vehicle), Lumatronic (CNC cutting, audiovisual rentals), laser cutters, metalworkers, and carpenters. It is a community asset that has few peers in Toronto: truly a space where artists can dream and make massive art. We have also hosted a series of popular welding classes to help others learn how to turn their vision into steel reality. The Dragon's Lair (aka About the 2018 Team)Kevin Bracken, Cat herder-in-chief: Kevin has a lengthy portfolio of creating huge, outrageous projects, driven in no small part by his love for his adopted city, Toronto.  Marie Poliak, Chief designer: Marie Poliak is an artist who enjoys all things shiny. Co-owner of a satirical fashion label, mother of dragons, and all around sweetie pie. Marie enjoys long walks on the moon while casually plotting a path to global domination. Matt Von Wilde, Generalissimo: Matt is the head honcho of house music collective Secret Society, as well as being a badass carpenter and metalworker.  Stacy Campbell, Fire Lead: A member of I.A.T.S.E Local 873, Stacy specializes in special effects and makeup artistry, as well as a core member of our flame effects team.Christiane Yerex, Fire Maiden: Christiane has been there since the beginning, a true ride-or-die badgyal. Ben Cormier, The Man: Ben is the man, also an explosively talented resident DJ.Alex Borins, heir to the welding mask: Alex's incredible ability to learn is matched only by his inexhaustible energy. Fixes everything from bikes to soundsystems using only a hairdryer.  Patrick Vipond, Chief welder: Patrick is Heavy Meta's deus ex machina, off-roading enthusiast and welder. Nikki Sin, Media Team: Nikki is nearly every event on the road, tirelessly documenting and hyping the dragon. Alex Gold, Behind the scenes: Alex's city-A.D.H.D. is unparalleled and if he could just figure out where the hell he lives, maybe he'd have more time to work on the damn dragon. Jesse Champagne, Resident DJ: Jesse may be one of those "wear black while spinning minimal" types, but we love him all the same.Alex Lebedev, electronics: Alex has been there through thick and thin, making stuff work and bringing his unique know-how to difficult problems.Jamie Chebodiac, viking: Jamie comes to nearly every event on the road, while not busy appearing on made-in-Toronto TV shows like The Expanse and Killjoys. Ellis Briery, Assistant welder: Ellis is the resident cat/mascot, also pretty handy with engines and power tools. Prodigal Swan AlumSpecial thanks to the dragon family: Dani Cullimore, Petro Vesna, Site 3 Fire Arts, Dustin T. Hoffman, Austin Simpson, Chris Polley, Nikki Sin, Travis Johnson, Lolita Devlin, Olivia Coombe, Alina Dee, Dian Carlo, Geordie, Lindsay Millard, Priya Sarin, Jordan Snyder, Oz Carroll, Caspar Cash, Simon Plashkes, Mikale Pilgrim, Tiphane Leonard, Pavel Tchourliaev, Brian Dunseith, Miruna Toma, David Fradkin, Matt Languay, Patrick Brambley, Dasha Pyat, Patrick Leckie, Ryan Smythe, Laura Brien, Emma Duggan, Ben Retan, Andrea Shehara, Jacqueline Fernandez, Tamara Moskaliuk, Jay Ould, Christine Irving, Mell Barry, Sam Jarvis, Darryn Coleman, Jesse Champagne, Marina Izvekova, Ryan Wemyss, Maaor Ziv, Tim Sandik, Darcy Holt, Brittany Wharton, Sofia Timkovski, Dustin Nantais, Air`leth Aodhfin, Mike Dineen, JELO, George Hatiras, Robb G, Stephan Larose, Thomas Cardin, and Kevin's mom. Perks $5 - High FiveThis is like you giving us a high five - thanks!$10 - A Thank You Digital Postcard from The ArtistsOur heartfelt gratitude, and a personalized digital photo postcard of the dragon at Burning Man.$20 - Dine in Valhalla (VIP ticket to the Burning Man Farewell Party)This ticket grants you VIP admission to the dragon itself at the next Metaverse party - mid-August date. $20 - Heavy Meta StickerA die-cut, high-quality Heavy Meta sticker for your car, laptop, mutant vehicle, tiny home, RV, flamethrower, etc. $40 - Dragon Rider acrylic pendant CNC-cut, 1/4"-thick acrylic Heavy Meta text logo pendant.$60 - Heavy Meta ShirtPrinted in North America on 100% cotton tee. White on black, unisex sizes S - XXL.$60 - Heavy Meta Tank TopPrinted in North America on 100% cotton tee. White on black, unisex sizes S - XXL.$100 - Dragon Rider steel pendantCNC plasma cut 1/4"-thick steel Heavy Meta logo pendant.$300 - One-of-a-Kind Watercolor by Marie PoliakMarie will paint you a one-of-a-kind 6" x 8" watercolor of Heavy Meta, one-person portrait, a couple's portrait, or a pet.  $500 - DJ Set on the dragonAre you ready to drop some sick beats on the playa? Spin whatever you want on our 10,000-watt soundsystem for 2 hours. $500 - Hand-hammered steel helmetMatt Von Wilde will hand-hammer you a steel helmet in the Spartan Wraith or Spartan Warrior style. Comes with weathered, pitted, battle-blemished finish. Your tinfoil hat is now obsolete.Above: Actual helmets made by Matt $1,000 - Customize our license plateChoose our license plate, up to 8 characters, to say anything you want! We would like it to say HVYMETA but you might want it to say SAMRULEZ or something. (We reserve the right to veto hateful phrases.) $3,750 - Party anywhere in OntarioWe will bring Heavy Meta to your festival, concert, bar mitzvah, children's birthday party, raids on an enemy kingdom, grandparents' wedding anniversary, and more! Comes complete with soundsystem, flame effects, lighting effects, trained operators, and DJs if requested. Available anywhere in Ontario. $8,000 - Party anywhere in North AmericaWe will bring Heavy Meta to your festival, concert, bar mitzvah, children's birthday party, quinceañera, grandparents' wedding anniversary, and more! Comes complete with soundsystem, flame effects, lighting effects, trained operators, and DJs if requested. Everything you see in the photos is removable, and is able to be stored inside or on top of the bus. During transport, Heavy Meta will simply look like a black school bus with things strapped to the roof, and measure 11.5' high, well below the legal maximum height of 13.5'.   How do you get it to events, including Burning Man?We  drive it; it's a bus!I don't have money to contribute, how else can I help?We are always looking for volunteers to help us in the shop, which is located near Dupont & Ossington in Toronto. Please e-mail hello@heavymeta.ca to get involved.What happens if you don't raise $10,000? So far we have funded this project with the help of personal money, private donors, grants from Great Lakes Experimental Arts and BurnT, and fundraiser parties.
