story:
Un véhicule pour Coco Time Design !

- Je suis un jeune créateur de 22 ans.
Je réalise des créations artisanales à partir de noix de coco.
Je suis dans une démarche écologique car j'utilise un bois naturel et renouvelable.

- Mes créations sont un mariage entre le Roots et le luxe donnant naissance à un art unique et somptueux.

- J'ai déjà réalisé de nombreux évènements tel que le Festival de Cannes, la Foire de Paris etc..
J'ai également reçu les encouragements de plusieurs Artistes et Journaux tel que: Le Parisien et le France Antilles...



 
Mais il est très difficile de vivre de son art et encore plus lorsque l'on ne   peut pas se déplacer avec son matériel.

- Sans véhicule il m'est impossible de participer aux évènements qui se déroule un peu partout en France, voir à l'étranger.

- Avec votre aide je pourrai, je l'espère, acheter un véhicule qui me permettra enfin d'élargir mon espace de vente et de promotionner des produits naturels et de bonne qualité.

 

Pour quoi seulement 1000 € ?

- Après de nombreux devis et une longue réflexion, il me faudrait en réalité 12 000 € pour mettre à bien ce projet.

1000 € serait une première base, j'espère obtenir plus.

Votre aide est nécessaire. Seul, je ne pourrais pas avoir cette somme avant  2 ou 3 ans.


Si l'objectif n'est pas atteint, où les fonds iront il ?

- Si l'objectif n'est pas atteint, les fonds seront conservés jusqu'à l'optention total de la somme pour acheter le véhicule. ( Je ne m'arrêterai pas sur un échèc ! Je continue jusqu'au bout, peut importe les moyens )
  

Quel est l'impact de votre participation, minime soit elle ?

- C'est avec des grains de riz que l'on remplit le sac, non ?

Un don minime soit-il, m'encourage à continuer et à me battre pour avancer, car il signifie que des personnes croient en mon talent et en mon art.

 

D'autres façons d'aider ?

Certaines personnes ne peuvent pas contribuer financièrement, mais cela ne veut pas dire qu'elles ne peuvent pas aider :

- Demandez aux gens de passer le mot et de faire de la publicité sur les réseaux sociaux, bouche à oreille etc.. Rien n'est possible sans vous.

- Utilisez également les outils de partage indiegogo.

 

                Le naturel vous appelle, répondez lui !
                               Coco Time Design

story:
Karl has had a lifelong interest in custom cars.  During his time off from running the bakery he owned with his wife, he spent his time restoring vintage cars and boats in his garage.  All of that came to a halt in 1999 when Karl suffered a major heart attack followed by multiple medical emergencies eventually resulting in the loss of his leg in 2006.  With waning health and no steady income, Karl has had to put most of his custom car dreams on hold.  In 2012, Karl saved up enough money to start another project.  This time, instead of restoring a car, he began to build a traditionally styled custom truck in his garage with the goal of displaying the truck at the historic Detroit Autorama.  

The inspiration for this truck comes from the legendary custom car/truck builders of the late 40's and 50's such as Harry Westergard, Sam and George Barris, Valley Customs, as well as Detroit customizers Clarkaiser and The Alexander Brothers.  The truck itself is being built from various Ford model years and styles to create a one of a kind traditional custom.  All of the work has been done in the family garage by Karl himself, with the help of a few friends and family members.  

Parts of the project that are currently completed include:

-Chassis is cleaned and painted

-Truck cab has been chopped and channeled

-New floor installed in cab

-Front fenders modified and awaiting installation

-All parts have been stripped and coated in epoxy primer

-Cab has been mounted to frame and doors have been hung

-Front seat modification has been started

-Firewall modification complete

The immediate need for the truck is funding to finish the suspension as well as starting work to build/buy/restore an engine.  Various accessories such as grills, mirrors, tires, and a useable truck box also need to be purchased or built. The plan is to use no parts newer than 1953 to maintain the traditional custom style. 

The project has reached a point where funding is needed in order to continue the build.  While the goal amount for the next phase is $2500, any contributions will allow Karl to continue to move forward with the project! Thank you for your interest and help with our campaign to keep the Karl's dream and the art of traditional custom builds alive!

story:
Summary

The White Page is an artist-run space and residency program.
Our mission is to provide an accessible art space that supports emerging artists through a residency program, regular exhibitions, and open events aimed to inspire collaboration that enlivens the community.
Over the past year and a half, The White Page has hosted:
-16 exhibitions
-2 artist talks
-8 artist critiques
-3 film screenings
-6 studio visits
We've also hosted other artist-run events in our space like Creative Chats by MPLS Creates and Synth Meets by Low-Gain Electronics. In addition, we have become fiscally sponsored by Springboard for the Arts, a 501(c)(3) organization. 
 
We want to continue to give our residents and community a space to experience all forms of art. Because The White Page has outgrown our current location, we are using this campaign to help us expand. We are merging our work-space with seven other artists to better our facilities and to grow our studio community. This transition will provide more spacious and more varied resources including a:
-Darkroom 
-Printshop
-Expanded woodshop
-Ceramic studio
-Classroom/Workshop space
-Bigger gallery
With these additional facilities and sets of skills, we will be able to host a variety of events, exhibitions and workshops. Our new location is in Powderhorn, a diverse neighborhood that allows for foot-traffic and better accessibility by public transit.
With your help, this expansion will allow us to secure our future as a gallery and residency program. 


What We Need 

The $14,000 in funding will go towards:
-Residency costs--$1,800
-Rent of Gallery space for one year--$9,000
-Insurance--$500
-Programming costs--$2,700

The Impact

As four women, we all believe that art can be used as a source of empowerment, and we have found strength in participating in this project from the ground up.  We know that art plays an important role in learning and want to continue contributing creativity to the Twin Cities.  
The White Page has had a lot of successes in our short time as a collective. Now that we've established ourselves and learned how to work as arts administrators, we are going to restructure our programming to give our artists longer residencies. They will have more time to work, receive feedback, and edit. This will also create more flexibility in our schedule to host events open to the community. 

Risks & Challenges

The White Page was founded a year and a half ago. Its four original founders are still leading TWP today as we grow. The success we've had in hosting exhibitions, talks, workshops, and events has made us feel appreciated by the Twin Cities. We've outgrown our current location much faster than anticipated and look forward to facing new challenges that come with growth.   
Our new space will allow us to create new systems for sustainability. We will be able to implement regular workshops and programming. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Artists Justin Meyers and Jason Lescalleet have created a wonderful listening experience in honor of our cause.  It's an album available from Glistening Examples and all proceeds from the sale of this album will be donated to The White Page.
If you're interested in experimental electronic music, then here's your chance to support us while also having access to music that was created especially for us.
Click here to stream or download the music, or you can order a CD that also includes a digital download with your purchase.


Please help to spread the word about our campaign, and help us to expand and provide the best for our artists-in-residence and community!

story:
*DISCLAIMER- THIS IS NOT A JOKE, OR A MOCKERY, ALTHOUGH IT IS HUMOROUS TO SOME PEOPLE, FAST AWARENESS WAS STARTED BY A PERSON WITH AUTISM AND IN NO WAY SUPPORTS BULLYING OR TRIVIALIZING OF THIS MOST IMPORTANT AND BEAUTIFUL CHALLENGE!*

May is annual Fast Awareness Month, a celebration of everything from Sonic the Hedgehog all the way to sanaiic the ehdgeahog. It also is a play off "Autism Awareness Month" which is a beautiful and needed event we honor and humbly follow.

Autism, in all its pain and beauty, helps shape the landscape of our internet lives and the art and culture the internet radiates outward into IRL. 

 
We hope to spread awareness across the internet, but there is not enough Sanic in the world to help us!

We have decided to take up a billboard advertisement that depicts Sanic, a hilarious and lovable disambiguation of Sonic the Hedgehog. With this, we hope to launch a campaign that depicts Autism in a positive light, and shows the giftedness of the humans it effects. When we say "support autism" we mean support the autists, and their artist inside, their lives, their gifts, their families, to lift them up, and act as a helping hand in allowing the effect they have on our lives to deepen.

All proceeds from this piece of art will go towards research in chelation therapy.

help us make this dream come true.

it would be very fast of you.

-Team Faste

AUTISM POSITIVITY!

story:
The Baltimore Jewelry Center is an educational nonprofit and a resource for jewelers, metalsmiths, and artists in the Baltimore area. We exist because we care deeply about educating people in the art and craft of metalsmithing and jewelry, about designing and making jewelry, and about providing a supportive and nurturing environment for others who aspire to do the same. The Baltimore Jewelry Center offers a range of adult and teen classes and workshops for all levels of metalsmithing and jewelry fabrication, as well as affordable bench rental for students and practicing jewelers and metalsmiths, providing access to specialized equipment. As a resource for metalsmiths and jewelers, we provide the necessary support for people wanting to learn a tool-intensive craft. We offer business and marketing support to artists to help them create sustainable business plans and keep them living and working in Baltimore. We are excited to be an active contributor to the artist and craft community in Baltimore, with expanding programming that includes exhibitions, lectures, and sales opportunities for our community and the public.

We recognize Baltimore’s rich history in metalwork, fabrication, and jewelry. We want these traditions to continue and flourish in a new generation of makers, assisting in the revitalization of the city through the passing on of hand skills and the support of creative endeavors. We contribute to the overall quality of life in Baltimore by offering hands-on art opportunities and art education to the public. We believe the learning of hand skills is a way to empower and strengthen our communities in Baltimore.

(Clockwise from top left) Instructors and Board Members at Points of Departure exhibition opening, brooches by student Linda Wilson, Revolution bracelet by student and exhibiting artist Beverly Tadeu, Instructor Shana Kroiz teaching a Ring in a Day workshop, Royal brooch by  Instructor Shana Kroiz, Cast Seedpod necklace by Instructor Kirsten Rook.

We began operating the Baltimore Jewelry Center as an independent nonprofit organization less than a year ago. For more than 20 years, the Jewelry Center was part of the Maryland Institute College of Art (MICA), offering classes to continuing studies and full-time students. When MICA announced in 2012 that it would discontinue the program due to budget constraints, we were of course very disappointed, but we also were determined and excited to keep this thriving, well-loved program alive as a community-based metals and jewelry makerspace. Our excitement increased as we realized that as an independent organization we could now offer more educational opportunities to a more diverse range of students. Additionally, we could expand our programming to provide facilities and support for practicing jewelry artists, and actively participate in Baltimore’s artist and maker community. We got down to work and the Baltimore Jewelry Center was formed! In June of 2014 we opened our doors and in August 2014 we received our official designation as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit. Since opening our doors, we have educated over 180 students! We are proud to be the only community-based metals and jewelry makerspace in the Baltimore region.

We are incredibly grateful for our loyal and supportive community of students and instructors, which continues to thrive and grow, and we want to give as many people as possible the opportunity to experience all that we have to offer.

(Clockwise from top left) Instructor Beth Pohlman teaching forging to a beginning metals class, Globe necklace by Instructor April Wood, necklace by student and Board Member Mary Raivel, end of semester display of student work, silver ring made in the Ring in a Day workshop.

We need your help to support our growing community and goals! Our success depends on our ability to expand our programming and increase awareness of, enthusiasm for, and participation in all that we have to offer.  When we started the Baltimore Jewelry Center, we knew we needed a larger space in a location with greater public visibility and connection to the arts community. Though our current building met our basic needs when we were part of MICA, its tucked away location is a bit hard to find, with no foot traffic and limited visibility. Our current space has no exhibition, office, or retail spaces, and its size limits us to holding one class at a time. We have 35 desks and tables that we use as jeweler’s benches, though they are not designed for that purpose. Moreover, the building is situated in a floodplain on the banks of the Jones Falls. Last year, a flood destroyed our flooring and damaged expensive equipment, furniture, and materials. While this is not a common occurrence, we’d rather not experience it again!

So on July 1, 2015, the Baltimore Jewelry Center will move to our new space - the historic Centre building at 10 E. North Avenue - which will meet our needs and thereby allow us to realize our vision and better serve Baltimore and our community! Our new space is bigger, and the building has high visibility, foot traffic, and a great location in the heart of the thriving Station North Arts and Entertainment District, a rapidly expanding arts district designated by the state of Maryland. The Centre is being redeveloped by the nonprofit Jubilee Baltimore to meet the specific needs of the Baltimore Jewelry Center and other tenants, which include the MICA and Johns Hopkins University joint film program, several nonprofits, and a computer gaming company.

The Station North Arts and Entertainment District is also home to the historic Parkway Theatre (under renovation to be the new home of the Maryland Film Festival); the Station North Tool Library, a tool lending library; Red Emma’s bookstore and coffee house; Baltimore Print Studios, a public access print studio; the MICA Studio Center; the historic Motor House building (currently being redeveloped into artist studios); Artist and Craftsman Supply; numerous other galleries and performance spaces, and a number of popular restaurants and bars. A major Amtrak/commuter rail station and a light rail stop are within easy walking distance, as are stops on numerous city bus lines. With our move to The Centre, we will be an active contributor to the ongoing revitalization of Station North, bringing much needed investment and vitality to Baltimore.


The Centre at 10 E. North Avenue under construction, base plan for our space

The total cost for the Baltimore Jewelry Center to move to our new space is considerable - $600,000. This covers construction costs for the build-out of our new space and related services, such as architectural fees, ventilation, fixtures, and new equipment for our studio.

We are proud beyond words that we’ve already raised $545,000, 91% of our goal, through grants and individual donations! We only have 9% left, but we need to raise this money as soon as we can before our July 1 move-in date...and that’s where you come in! Construction on our space has already begun and will soon be complete!

HELP US RAISE THE LAST 9%, $55,000, by June 20 to pay for the following one-time expenses and to have the items below installed before we open for business on July 13:

  • Moving costs (movers, security and rent deposit): $20,000
  • 46  jewelers’ benches ( a jeweler’s “bench” is an individual’s work space): $25,000 - The jeweler’s bench is the tool of utmost importance in a metals and jewelry studio. It is the space where the majority of work is completed, where community and camaraderie is built in a communal studio, and it is the largest visible fixture in the studio. Our benches are a critical centerpiece of our space and the place where our students spend the majority of their time in our studio. We have worked with our architect to design benches that are beautiful as well as functional, and make the most efficient use of our new space. These benches will be designed and sized specifically for our space, with integrated electrical outlets, but they are ultimately less expensive than purchasing pre-made individual jeweler’s benches. 

  • Sliding partition wall (to allow two classes to be held at the same time): $10,000 – This sliding wall was designed specifically for our space to be used to divide our workspace into two sections so that we can have two classes running concurrently or bench rental and a class running at the same time. Additionally, the sliding wall, when collapsed, functions as a display and inspiration board.

1. Donate to the campaign! Any amount helps, no matter how big or small. We would like to thank you for your support by offering you a variety of wonderful incentives, including Baltimore Jewelry Center swag, services and other sought-after and valuable items!  Check out the detailed descriptions and pictures below for the perks offered at each contribution level (see the gallery for larger images of the perks)! AND REMEMBER - your contributions to the Baltimore Jewelry Center are tax-deductible!

2. Like our Facebook page and follow us on Twitter and Pinterest, where we will be posting updates about the build out and the campaign.

3. Share our campaign with your friends and family and on your own social media outlets! The wider this is shared the better!
story_txt:
The Baltimore Jewelry Center is an educational nonprofit and a resource for jewelers, metalsmiths, and artists in the Baltimore area. We exist because we care deeply about educating people in the art and craft of metalsmithing and jewelry, about designing and making jewelry, and about providing a supportive and nurturing environment for others who aspire to do the same. The Baltimore Jewelry Center offers a range of adult and teen classes and workshops for all levels of metalsmithing and jewelry fabrication, as well as affordable bench rental for students and practicing jewelers and metalsmiths, providing access to specialized equipment. As a resource for metalsmiths and jewelers, we provide the necessary support for people wanting to learn a tool-intensive craft. We offer business and marketing support to artists to help them create sustainable business plans and keep them living and working in Baltimore. We are excited to be an active contributor to the artist and craft community in Baltimore, with expanding programming that includes exhibitions, lectures, and sales opportunities for our community and the public.We recognize Baltimore’s rich history in metalwork, fabrication, and jewelry. We want these traditions to continue and flourish in a new generation of makers, assisting in the revitalization of the city through the passing on of hand skills and the support of creative endeavors. We contribute to the overall quality of life in Baltimore by offering hands-on art opportunities and art education to the public. We believe the learning of hand skills is a way to empower and strengthen our communities in Baltimore.(Clockwise from top left) Instructors and Board Members at Points of Departure exhibition opening, brooches by student Linda Wilson, Revolution bracelet by student and exhibiting artist Beverly Tadeu, Instructor Shana Kroiz teaching a Ring in a Day workshop, Royal brooch by  Instructor Shana Kroiz, Cast Seedpod necklace by Instructor Kirsten Rook.We began operating the Baltimore Jewelry Center as an independent nonprofit organization less than a year ago. story:
THE MERMAIDS ARE COMING!

Long Beach artists Denise Collins and Laura Bykowski, founders of the original Mermaid Art Studio, plan to relocate to a new home in the heart of the West End as part of Long Beach’s post-Sandy recovery. Bruised but not broken...rebuilding Long Beach one paint stroke at a time!

The Mermaid Art Studio will be a community-focused Center for the Arts.  The studio will offer after-school classes for elementary school aged children, tweens and teens, in addition to adult classes and workshops in Printmaking, Book Binding, Painting, Drawing, Fiber Arts, Weaving, Recycled Art, Papier-mâché, and much more.

Open studio hours will be offered during the day as well as on Fridays for Teen Night. Birthday Parties, Ladies Nights and First Friday events are part of the studio’s programs.

 

BRUISED, NOT BROKEN

Last October Long Beach suffered tremendous devastation in the wake of Hurricane Sandy. One school remains closed and the future of our hospital remains unclear. But the community is closer and stronger than ever. Evidence of our “Bruised but not Broken” attitude is everywhere—homeowners are lifting their houses and rebuilding smarter. Construction on our oceanfront boardwalk is well underway. While some businesses were lost to the storm, others are springing up with fresh ideas and energy. Opening in September 2013, less than one year after Hurricane Sandy changed our city, The Mermaid Art Studio will help repair and strengthen Long Beach’s arts community.

YOU CAN HELP!

Join us in spreading the message of “Bruised not Broken” in our beloved Long Beach. You can help us build The Mermaid Art Studio by contributing to our fundraising campaign.

Our goal of $12,500 is the bare minimum needed for construction and materials to launch our studio space and bring much needed art, beauty and sense of community back to the West End.

 

  • $9,000 for construction materials and labor: flooring, lighting, slop sink, shelving and storage space (as you can see, the space is just a shell right now).
  • $1,500 furniture and equipment (tables, stools, easels, flat file)
  • $2,000 for art making materials and supplies (paint, canvas, paper, brushes, bookbinding tools, paper cutters, and more). While we plan to keep costs down by upcycling/using donated materials whenever possible, we are starting with a blank slate and need basic supplies for making art!

 

NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL and ALL will be recognized on our website.

You can give any amount you desire or select a perk level! 

Please spread the word: share us with your friends and families and even strangers! The more the merrier! We deeply appreciate your contribution in making our studio dream a reality.

Bruised but not broken….The Mermaid Art Studio: Rebuilding Long Beach, NY one paint stroke at a time!

"Like" The Mermaid Art Studio on Facebook for news and updates, including our grand opening in September, as well as upcoming classes and workshops: https://www.facebook.com/TheMermaidArtStudio

 

More about Denise and Laura

Denise Collins Gilgannon
Hi! My name is Denise Collins, creator of the Mermaid Art Studio, along with my good friend and fellow Long Beach Artist, Laura Bykowski. I am a Long Beach resident (19 years) and Certified K-12 Art teacher (MS ArtEd./LIU/CWPost), teaching 10 years in the Long Beach School District. As an undergraduate, centuries ago, I majored in both Social Welfare and Art; wasn't sure if I wanted to save the world or paint it! Art kept beckoning me. I have studied at the Arts Students League, The School of Visual Arts in NYC, UMAss Art New England,  as well as privately in the Art Studio Of John F. Murray, a classically trained Figure and Portrait artist. I am always learning and taking workshops to this day. I have worked as a social worker, graphic artist, freelance illustrator and Art teacher. At this point in my life, I believe my greatest strength as an artist lies in my teaching, especially with children and young adults.I am extremely fortunate to have realized this opportunity...and to keep it growing and evolving!

A few summers ago Laura and I began teaching Art classes out of a small garage which was the beginning of The Mermaid Art Studio. The experience made me realize how vitally important it is for children to have a community based Art studio, in addition to school, where they can express themselves all year long. Hurricane Sandy only fortified my conviction that this was crucial. I see Art as being a necessary vehicle for community restoration and rebirth and happily, I live in a community that supports this belief and nurtures it in their children!

Laura Bykowski
Hi, I'm Laura and I'm a preservation librarian, bookbinder, and a knitter who dyes and spins her own yarn. My vision of The Mermaid Art Studio is a place where folks can come to imagine, explore and express their creative spirit. In a world where so much is digital and virtual, it is deeply gratifying to create something tangible and completely unique.

In addition to entrepreneurial spirit and artistic vision, I bring over 20 years of start up/business experience and project management skills to the Mermaid Studio. I'm a graduate of The New School and CW Post/Palmer School. I'm also the co-founder of another Long Beach & web-based business, Beach Girls Purls. My background is in project management and technology so between Denise and myself, we've got both the creative and business sides of the studio covered.

story:
Brief

Can you imagine being a part of something that will be seen by millions of people and will still be here in 5000 years?  Help me complete this magnificent bronze sculpture.

 

Story

Sculpture for the Ages.

St. Michael the Archangel is one of the most popular images in all Christianity; the patron saint of soldiers, sailors, police officers and those who protect and keep us safe as well as more than 50 countries and cities around the world.

As an artist, the commission to produce a sculpture of St. Michael was a dream come true, to produce it in bronze at a heroic 15 feet and weighing more than 3 tons was a once in a lifetime opportunity.  And what better place for such a spectacular sculpture than the beautiful grounds of Mary, Queen of the Universe, the National Basilica located here in Orlando between the magical worlds of Disney and Universal Studios.  The Shrine attracts millions of visitors from every corner of the world with it’s magnificent grounds, architecture and collection of original art.

When completed and installed this September, the nine foot Michael with his twelve foot wings will stand guardian at the entrance to the Shrine’s bridge atop a five foot half ballard made of concrete and sculpted with a representation of evil emerging from the earth.

This impressive project has been funded by a single donor from Chicago, and although I have donated my time and talent to its completion for almost 2 years, complications in design and cost overruns in the casting of such an enormous piece has left a deficit, which I am working to make up.  In addition to the massive size, which has required me to work in sections, consideration had to be given to Florida’s weather conditions that can produce hurricane force winds in excess of 150 mph.  To meet the challenge we developed a complex stainless steel skeleton to branch the entire sculpture, then extended it six feet underground into a concrete pad and pylons weighing more than 8 tons.

Although the technology employed to support this work and that used to create the foam armature is state of the art, the process of sculpting and then casting the clay original dates back to the Bronze Age of 4000 B.C.  Little has changed through the ages, particularly in the casting which is done in the Lost Wax process, identical to the method used to produce the beautiful bronze art of the Renaissance.

Take a few moments to enjoy the accompanying video for a chronology of the work and a brief documentary of the process and steps involved in creating such a piece of art.

 

What Can You Do?

Today’s social media has allowed projects like this to touch tens of thousands, and provides us a platform to reach out to complete this work.  We are only eight weeks away.  Make a donation and help spread the word through your email, Facebook and Twitter contacts.  Every contribution makes a difference, little things add up.  When I work in clay, I build up in a process called stippling.  That is adding tiny dots of clay one on top of the other until the form develops.  From a distance the piece appears to be one entity, but up close, it’s obvious that in reality it is millions of tiny dots working together.  I estimate the sculpture of St. Michael incorporates more than 6.5 million of these little pieces of clay.  Proof that every little bit no matter how small has a place.

For those who can do more, please consider one of the perks accompanying this proposal.  Bronze, by its very nature can last thousands of years.  And we all know someone who has watched over and protected us, like St. Michael.  What better way to honor your own personal guardian be it, soldier, firefighter, policeman, EMT or any first responder than a personal memorial imbedded in a time capsule enclosed within St. Michael’s base.  (See Perk of $250 and $500)  Send us your dedication, the name of your protector and let us preserve that memory for generations to come, a millennium or more in the future.

 

We’re Almost There

Watch this site for weekly updates on our fundraising and on the sculpture of St. Michael.  As work progresses we will be adding new photos of the casting, finishing and installation.  Join us and be a part of something that will last for 5000 years. 

Finally, thank you.  Thank you for your financial support and your help in spreading the word.  There are few opportunities in life to be a part of something larger than ourselves, something lasting.  It is said that beauty, like art, reminds us of our destiny, it sets us back on our path, fills us with new hope, gives us the courage to live to the full, the unique gift of life.

                                                                                                                           

-Loura Parks Dobbs

Finally, thank you.  Thank you for your financial support and your help in spreading the word.  There are few opportunities in life to be a part of something larger than ourselves, something lasting.  It is said that beauty, like art, reminds us of our destiny, it sets us back on our path, fills us with new hope, gives us the courage to live to the full, the unique gift of life.
                                                                                                                            
-Loura Parks Dobbs

story:
What is the Black Rock French Quarter?

The Black Rock French Quarter is a village at Burning Man, composed of 21 different theme camps, each of which strives to make its own unique contribution to Black Rock City.

Images from the French Quarter, captured by Todd Gardiner.


What are the theme camps within the Black Rock French Quarter?

In this, the third year of the Black Rock French Quarter, the village will feature a bakery and ice cream parlor, a voodoo botanica, a bathhouse that gifts custom scrubs and oils, a live jazz band, a coffee house that roasts raw beans on playa, a bedouin eatery, a vineyard, a brewery, a supper club, a bathhouse, a wine cellar, a ramshackle whiskey bar, an elegant cocktail lounge, a fresh produce market, a cantina featuring jam sessions, a hotel, and a photo booth producing commemorative postcards.

Image of the French Quarter at night, captured Neil Girling.


How is Black Rock Asiatown related to all this?

Within the back alleys of the French Quarter is another village, Black Rock Asiatown, consisting of a tiki lounge, a shibari teahouse, a dojo, and twisting streets covered in black light reactive artwork.

Images from the streets of Asiatown, created by Deb Cable.


How did it all start?

We founded the Black Rock French Quarter in 2011, in thanks to Burning Man for the profound contribution the festival has made to our lives - it was my 10th year on playa, and I felt the need to share something special. So it was that one of the most talented, creative, wonderful groups of people I have ever had the pleasure of struggling with, raised a living vision of the city of my heart, New Orleans, in the Black Rock Desert.

Stilt walkers looking for the upstairs stilt bar, captured by Kristen Lanum.


What Is The Money For?

The target for this project has been set to cover the $10,000 it costs to have our 45 foot box trailer and 50 foot flatbed trailer repaired and shipped from LA to BRC and back again.

On top of that basic expense, we need to replace, reconfigure, and repaint much of the buildings themselves, to make the annual construction of the village more sustainable. Many MANY great minds came together to develop our building style, that we hope will transform other camps, and allow BRC to look and feel even more like the cities of our dreams - but it needs serious refinement to be easier to assemble, disassemble, and pack. In total, we would like to raise $16000 after the fees taken by Indiegogo, although we'll make due with whatever funds are available.


A portion of the steel frame we need to transport.

What Is The Bang For The Buck?

One of the most exciting aspects of this project is that everything we build can return to Burning Man year after year - your contribution is helping to grow a part of Black Rock City that started in 2011 and will be bigger and better in 2013 and beyond - if we can raise the funds to get to the playa this year, and streamline our building style, we foresee minarets, castles, skyscrapers, and villas in the future of Burning Man.

Most importantly, the target we set is only a fraction of the actual costs of creating a thriving village of interconnected camps like the bakery, coffee house, and gumbo cookery. Not covered here is all the equipment already purchased or donated by our members, including propane ovens for the bakery, a refrigerator and generator for the wine cellar, sound system and generator for the jazz band, stoves and prep areas for the gumbo cookery, etc. Also not covered are the wines produced by our vintners, the brews produced by our brewers, the ingredients used by our bakers, etc. The money raised here to return the French Quarter to playa makes it possible to bring all these other contributions together.

 

The French Quarter from Terry on Vimeo.

story:
Nearly undestroyable fabric:

Cut -, scratch - and abrasion-resistant! 


About me:


I explore and study to find a nearly undestroyable fabric,  which is comfortable and suitable and fits in the everydays life.                     

The intended use of this fabric is the upholstery from chairs and other sitting accomodations. 

In which section the fabric is used at least should be decided by the customer. 

I have excellent experience in living together with cats.  In my family we have a lot of different cat breeds, mostly Savannahs and Bengals. 

Unfortunately living in company with so many cats makes a lot of damage on the upholstery and other furniture.  


This nuisance was the reason  my thought has started to grow:

A scratch-resist home,  where we can live in company with our cats without the annoying disadvantages. A home where a happy, petloving family can live without great nuisance of damaged and scratched furniture and no extra costs for repairs.  


So my exploration began:    


Quick I had a name: Zanner Resist - a combination of my lastname and a hint to the fabric.  

And than a long exhausting time of searching and arranging of what fabric is useful and a lot of rejection of what is not useable.

But now I have reached the point to say: 

"I have what I want!" 

Successfully planned and well grounded.  


Fabric details :

- comfortable to skin 

- scratch-resistant

- abrasion-resistant

A secret combination of different of fibers and other material!


And now it's in your hand if my idea has a future and enters your home.  

Its up to you, to make my dreams become true!  


I, as a passionated Cat-Fan think, there is no fabric for upholstery on the market, which is resistant against the claws of our beloved Tigers! 


Even if your financial situation doesn't allow you to sponsor my project,  it will also be helpful,  you as a Catowner and Petlover tell to your friends about my campaign and share it on social media like Facebook, Twitter, Google+ etc.  


Perks:


Shipping:

After campaign has finished,  I need minimum 1 month for shipping the perks to your home.  

Shipping and handling within EU is included. 

For international shipping outside the EU and Overseas please add the postal charges as shown below the different packages.  



If there is any error in my text, please apologize,  because this is not my language.  But I have tried my best to translate it into english.  I would be pleased if you let me know how to write it correctly!

story:
Who We Are:

Founded in 2005 by Shawn Lyons, Rabbithole has provided a platform for hundreds of artists, writers, musicians and performers through Rabbithole Projects, The Rabbithole Gallery and Performance Space, Rabbit Tales, and Movie Nights.

Rabbithole is also home to a creative education program for adults, Brooklyn Central,  an art school for all kids of all ages, Creatively Wild Art Studio,  a massage therapy studio, NYC Massage and Healing, and six artist’s studios.

What Needs Funding:

This campaign is to assist us in purchasing a proper air conditioner, which is imperative to our survival as a space.  Being one floor below street level, we are unable to properly create airflow during our events and rentals, and so it gets really REALLY hot down here! Because of the heat, we have a difficult time renting the space out which is what helps us survive. With your generous donation we will be able to cool down the space which will result in more studio bookings that fund the programs at Rabbithole.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to purchase the Air Conditioning System we will need to raise $15,000.  This is where you come in.  With every dollar donated we will be able to raise the money to purchase a proper AC to cool down the space.  Since we are located below street level we need an AC that does not depend on a window.  Once our goal is reached we will be able to curate more exhibitions and hold more events at Rabbithole, and we'll have the revenue to increase and further develop our programming.  We are also offering some really cool classes/massages/photo-shoot opportunities as a thank you... check them out!  ------>   

The Impact:

Rabbithole is not only a community of artists, we are compassionate about our vision and giving back to the neighborhood as a whole.  We love what we do, we want to stay, and we want to continue to serve DUMBO, NYC, and emerging culture through our programming, education, and artistic production.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Every little bit helps!  Please share our campaign and make some noise on twitter or your favorite social media outlets.  Thank you for the love!!

FOLLOW US ON INSTAGRAM

@RABBITHOLE_STUDIO

& TWITTER


@RABBITHOLESTUDIO 


& SHARE THE LOVE

story:
Murals And Girls consists of female spray can artists from all around the world who express themselves through their art. We are dedicated to doing our part to give back to the community by painting beautiful murals.

Murals And Girls is originally from Oakland, Ca where vandalism is a key contributor to the destruction of our home. By painting bright colored, uplifting murals in areas where vandalism was an everyday occurrence, we have cured our neighborhood of what has become an epidemic. Now that we have done what we can for our home town we decided to go a step further and do the same for home towns all over the world.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           

By donating, you would be helping us to continue to spread light, along with the strong talented women from each community on our World Tour. The murals we paint always reflect the character of each individual community. We are dedicated to the beautification of the neighborhood not only from the outside but also from the inside. We have found people have a much more pleasant reaction when they can see positive community oriented murals instead of vandalism and destruction.

What We Need & What You Get      

Our fundraising goal is $34,050 for the Los Angeles and New Mexico portion of our World Tour. 


Now it's time for a break down! The prices are for three people, two cities, Los Angeles and New Mexico (Murals And Girls Staff). We will be traveling the United States in the Murals And Girls RV now in Los Angeles California and then to New Mexico.


  1. Gas---$3000
  2. Food---$5400
  3. Dog Food---$800 (We love our pets, so...yes they are coming with us.)
  4. RV Maintenance---$1200 (Oil changes etc..)
  5. RV Park---$2600 (Most nights will be spent in the RV but showers and electricity are a must.)
  6. Laundry---$500
  7. Video Editing---$2000 (two videos)
  8. Filmography---$2000 (two videos)
  9. Assistants---$2000 (Two people at $500 each per tour stop)
  10. Paint Supplies---$600 (We have the spray paint covered this is for buff paint, rollers etc.)
  11. T-Shirt Printing---$3000
  12. Car Rental---$4000 (Most errands cannot be done in the RV)
  13. Communications---$950 (Phone, Internet)
  14. Artist Donation---$6000 (To be split up evenly between all of the artists. The girls do these murals for free but it is always nice to give them a little money toward the starving artist fund.
  • Total---$34,050

As a thank you for your contributions Murals And Girls has some special gifts to offer you. We are really excited to share these things with you, and we hope you will be excited too!!


  1. For the first 200 people who donate $10---We will shout you out to our nearly 20,000 followers on Instagram.
  2. For the first 200 people who donate $20---You will receive a Murals And Girls bumper sticker.
  3. For the first 100 people who donate $30---You will receive a Murals And Girls Sticker Pack
  4. For the first 60 people who donate $50---You receive a Murals And Girls T-Shirt
  5. For the first 30 people who donate $100---You received a Murals And Girls Custom Designed Hoodie
  6. For the first 20 people who donate $250---You will get recognized for your contribution by getting your name on a mural.
  7. For the first 5 people who donate $500---You will get to appear in one of our World Tour videos.
  8. For the first 5 people who donate $1000---You receive an invitation to one of the mural job sites where you can observe, meet the artists take photos and get a Murals And Girls T-shit.
  9. For the first 6 people who donate $1100---You will receive the Murals And Girls original bumper sticker, a Murals And Girls T-Shirt, a 2014 Murals And Girls calendar and have your name as a Co-Producer in our video credits.
  10. For the first 3 people who donate $1500---Be our guest for dinner! You will get to dine with Murals And Girls, our treat. Bring your appetite. You will also get a Murals And Girls sticker pack and a Murals And Girls T-Shirt.

  • If we don't reach our entire goal, the money we do raise will be added to other donations and sponsorship contributions until we have enough. We currently have a spray paint sponsor by Kobra Paint who donates spray paint for our World Tour murals, as well as a sponsorship by Jarritos Mexican Soda who helps to quench our thirst while we work hard to create a mural for everyone to enjoy. 

The Impact

Murals And Girls has already painted murals in Oakland, San Francisco, Santa Cruz, and Venice Ca. Check out our videos on Youtube, search word Murals And Girls. 


We have just arrived in Los Angeles and then we are headed to New Mexico, but we need your help. Since Murals And Girls gifts these murals to the communities we visit, we need to raise money for the trip there. By being a contributor you become and instant part of our family and are responsible for helping with the beautification of the community as well as, supporting the strong female spray can artists who leave a piece of their heart in every mural they paint.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate you can show your support by following us on Instagram @MuralsAndGirls. You can also check out our videos on Youtube, search word MuralsAndGirls. And most important you can always help by spreading the word about our Indiegogo campaign and all of these amazing women who can't wait to share their talents with a spray can in a community near you.

story: In the coming months I am very excited to start working on some new collaborative projects that focus more on makeup/costuming and photography/filmmaking. I am working on concepts for a series of more personal photo shoots that focus on my makeup artistry as well as helping my amazing friends with some marketing and performance projects. In order to do that I need to seriously upgrade my makeup kit and acquire some better photo equipment (namely, a DSLR). This is just a small stepping stone that will eventually branch out into many more ongoing projects and collaborations. I already have several projects planned with some fellow artists and am always open to collaborating with my awesome friends. Please feel free to check out my website for past projects and visuals and stay tuned for some bitchin' work in 2015!

story:
Art of the Danforth is a free, experimental art festival presented in the east end of Toronto.   Presented in 2010 and 2012 to great community enthusiasm, we're coming back again in just four short weeks!

A festival made up of a large number of public art projects, workshops, Art-in-Stores interventions and research, Art of the Danforth  is a reflexive and changing public art experiment that uses the structure of a ‘festival’ to transform, engage, uncover and discover the possible roles and functions of an artist in diverse and changing community. The festival takes place from May 2nd to May 11th 2014, roughly between Greenwood and Woodbine Avenues.

We need to pay artists!

We believe strongly in the importance of artists' contributions to our society - for their insights, speculation, analysis and humor.  As individuals, art can keep a person sane. As a society, artists can...well... keep a society sane.  

We have secured some funding through our amazing supporters, but this festival has always been produced on a shoe-string.   Our artists contribute a lot for very little, and every bit of money we can raise here will go back to them - as thank you and to help them live to create more art here and elsewhere. 

How you can help

  • If you can help us with a donation, please do so here
  • There's other ways to participate - please sign up for news in the east end - http://eastendarts.ca/east-end-arts-information-form/ 
  • come out to our events and volunteer - we'll be posting more information about how to do this on our website - www.artofthedanforth.com  in a couple weeks

Art of the Danforth is a free, experimental art festival presented in the east end of Toronto.   Presented in 2010 and 2012 to great community enthusiasm, we're coming back again in just four short weeks!A festival made up of a large number of public art projects, workshops, Art-in-Stores interventions and research, Art of the Danforth  is a reflexive and changing public art experiment that uses the structure of a ‘festival’ to transform, engage, uncover and discover the possible roles and functions of an artist in diverse and changing community. The festival takes place from May 2nd to May 11th 2014, roughly between Greenwood and Woodbine Avenues.We need to pay artists!We believe strongly in the importance of artists' contributions to our society - for their insights, speculation, analysis and humor.  As individuals, art can keep a person sane. As a society, artists can...well... keep a society sane.  We have secured some funding through our amazing supporters, but this festival has always been produced on a shoe-string.   Our artists contribute a lot for very little, and every bit of money we can raise here will go back to them - as thank you and to help them live to create more art here and elsewhere. How you can help
If you can help us with a donation, please do so here
There's other ways to participate - please sign up for news in the east end - http://eastendarts.ca/east-end-arts-information-form/ 
come out to our events and volunteer - we'll be posting more information about how to do this on our website - www.artofthedanforth.com  in a couple weeks

story:
Short Summary

As a former curator for the National art Gallery of The Bahamas, Director of Popop Studios International Center for the Visual Arts, and current Chief Creative Director for BahaMar, John Cox is one of the most significant contributors to the shape of the Bahamian art world. He is constantly working to create new spaces and opportunities for Bahamian artists at home and abroad. He gives more than he receives - this is your opportunity to give back! His presence at Art Volta NYC benefits everyone in the Bahamian art community. Help him help you by contributing to his entrance fee.

What We Need & What You Get

The Entrance Fee for Art Volta is $13,000. We want to raise $6,500 in the next three days as a birthday present for John. Whether we meet the goal or not, John will receive the money raised to put towards his entrance fee.

The Impact

John's presence at Art Volta is the presence of the Bahamian art world at an exhibition featuring the world' stop artists. When you contribute to this fund, you make it easier for John to do what he does well: promoting and making cutting-edge Bahamian art.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can make a contribution, but everyone can help by spreading the word and participating in art events across the island.

story:
Out of the personal pain A Quarter Blue's founder expereinced following sexual abuse, she began to understand how valuable healing was in becoming whole.  She founded A Quarter Blue to let others know they are not alone, there is a community for them. Therapists and artists come alongside of our families to facilitate healing.  We have groups in English and Spanish which include art therapy.  We need your help to continue our work.  

$3500 will give us the needed space and supplies to continue to work with these families this year.  We have walked this path with family members from 2 years old to sixty-ish.  Parents' marriages are healing.  Families are reuniting. Individuals are becoming whole.

We currently are working out of four different facilities loaned to us.  We desperately need a place to call home.  These funds will provide that needed rental space.  We will also purchase art supplies to continue our work. Please give us a hand.  Let others know about the need. Over A QUARTER of our neighborhoods are suffering alone...they don't need to-A Quarter Blue is here!

story:
What this is about

The neurobureau is a non-profit organization that supports “open neuroscience” — embracing the ideas that data, methods, and ideas can be freely shared. We are mostly scientists working in the field of brain mapping, as well as artists and curators interested in the brain (see here for a list of members). Since 2011, we have tried to push the boundaries between art and neuroscience during the Human Brain Mapping (HBM) conference. The HBM is the largest scientific conference exclusively dedicated to the field of brain mapping, with close to 3000 scientists attending. We want to organize three events:

  • a brain-art show, where established artists who work on the brain and the mind will display their work directly at the heart the conference. Some of the artists may attend to start collaborating with scientists.
  • a brain-art competition, where scientists are invited to submit their most beautiful illustrations of the brain.
  • a brain-art gala, where the winners of the brain-art competition are announced. 

We have been successful in organizing these events in Québec City, Canada, in 2011, as well as Beijing, China, in 2012. This year, we want to repeat the experience at the Washington State Convention Center, in Seattle, June 16-20 2013. We are delighted that Noah Hutton, who is running thebeautifulbrain.com, has accepted to curate the brain art show, and has already secured an impressive line-up of artists (an example below is "my soul" by Katherine Dowson). We have also booked the crocodile for the gala, a fantastic venue that has hosted concerts of Nirvana and Pearl Jam in the past. Unfortunately, we are still trying to figure out a model to fund this initiative. The HBM conference has been extremely supportive by providing us with premium space for the brain-art show, but there are still many other costs that need to be covered. To be true to the collaborative spirit of the neurobureau, we have decided to ask for direct support of the community. As we are not aware of many initiatives of this type on indiegogo or elsewhere, we are excited (and a bit anxious) to see how this unfolds. 

My Soul by Katherine Dowson

Empire States of Mind by Julia Buntaine

 

What We Need & What You Get

To make these events happen, we need:

  • to rent/buy material for the art-show. This includes poster boards, screens, pedestals and lights. Expected costs: 2000$
  • to ship all the pieces. Expected costs: 2000$
  • to rent the venue for the party. Expected costs: 1500$ 
  • to purchase/make all of the perks. Expected costs: 1000$

In the past, we have always managed to make everything happen, although this has been painful for our own bank accounts. So even if we don't reach our targets, most of the events will still take place. But we hope to find a sustainable model of funding for the years to come. Also, Noah Hutton has offered to prepare a catalogue for the art show, along with essays and interviews of the artists. This is one of several perks we have prepared for you. We will also offer buttons and free drinks for those of you that will attend the conference. Finally, we also offer the possibility to individuals and institutions to become official sponsors of the art events at HBM, and get their names/logos listed at the show, on the neurobureau website as well as during the gala. Our party in Québec city had more than 700 people attending, and the brain art show will be located in a strategic lobby where everyone attending the conference will go several times a day. This is thus a great way for an insitution to get visibility in addition to supporting a good cause. 

The Impact

If you had the opportunity to attend the HBM conference in the past you have seen how fantastic the art@HBM events are. Contributions of both artists and scientists have been very inspirational. As data vizualization is one of the big challenge in the study of the brain, these contributions have without any doubt a great scientific value. Artists such as Nathalie Regard have attended the conference and directly engaged with scientists. Beyond art, the gala has helped foster a collaborative spirit in the community, which matches the long-term goal of the neurobureau.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campain with your friends and colleagues. You can also get in touch with us if you want to help in person in Seattle, for example to set up the show or organize the party.

story:
www.miasuatheatre.com

MIASUA // みあすあ  THEATRE COMPANY 

is dedicated to keeping art free for the community. We strive to create interesting, socially relevant, and site-specific moments of theatrical to add an urban blunt, raw, fresh kicks to the beautiful north county San Diego community. 

---------------------------------------------------------

budget for first year

1. 12 Student Productions per year ($200 (Director) + $500 (budget) x 12 = $8,400)

2. 3 Portable bluetooth speakers ($200 x 3 = $600)

3. 1 Part Time Staff for 8-month youth part-time conservatory ($6,000)

4. 1 End of Year Banquet ($300)

5. 12 Meetings (Free! Sponsorship from Chin's Szechwan)

6. 1 3-day conference for youth ($1,000)

7. 5 scholarships for youth ($2,500)

8. Free Saturday Workshops for North County San Diego (36 x $300 = $7,800)

= $32,000

story:
The world is as sharp as the edge of a knife –Haida saying

Kestrel Tool is an artisan-owned and operated tool smith shop on Lopez Island in the Northwest corner of Washington state. Kestrel Tool consists of Gregg Blomberg, master toolmaker, and as of the beginning of this year, me Charlie Prince, the apprentice. 

You can help make sure that Kestrel Tools are available for future generations of artists and craftspeople.

We specialize in making handcrafted, top-of-the-line, artisan wood carving and sculpting tools. Our mainstays, the Crooked Knife and the Elbow Adze, are the traditional woodworking tools of Northwest Coast carvers. 

Kestrel finish adze, on a cedar box top.

  The crooked knife may have begun from the first curved wood cutting tool on the planet, the Beaver’s tooth. I can imagine people were inspired by the Beaver’s love of alder and the inherent efficiency of its design.

Kestrel Tool continues the North American woodworking tradition native to the Pacific Northwest Coast.  These tools are inherently different from the woodworking tools of European or Japanese heritage, and are used in a unique way, resulting in a unique art form. We are continually inspired by the Artists and Craftspeople who use our tools, and hope to help carry their art and culture into the future.

When I began learning to carve in the Northwest Coast styles, I couldn’t help but wonder, as the chips peeled off and fell around my feet, whether the shape of the tools evolved from the need to make the forms expressed in the artwork, or if the artwork evolved as it did from the shape of the tools. The two separate pieces, the art and the tools, are inseparable, and could hardly exist without each other. The result is magic.  The pleasure of creating a well made object is at least equal to the pleasure of using a well made tool to do so.

The Northwest Coast of North America is home to one of the world's greatest sculpting and woodworking traditions.  We owe a debt of gratitude to the generations of artists of coast for their inspiration.

 

Why this project?

Gregg has been looking for the right person to carry on this tradition and business since 2006.  After decades of producing the finest carving tools, he wants to spend more time with his family and work on his own art and all the tool ideas he has not had the time to develop.

Gregg had always hoped to find someone to carry on the business he had built, but had been unable to find an artisan who was interested in taking that on.  The business was almost sold to an Alaskan Native tribe, but the tribal corporation was unable to find someone within their membership to do it.  Gregg couldn't find anyone else and after what was to be a final run of tools, was ready to wrap it up, but at the same time felt reluctant to tell people that they could no longer get the tools they needed to make their artwork.  People kept ordering them, so he kept making them.

A few years ago I started carving with Gregg, and became interested in the business by way of using the tools.  My appreciation for the art form and love of carving evolved into a curiosity to know more about making the tools, why they are the way they are, and where they came from.

Joe David, Tla-o-qui-aht, one of the Northwest's top native artisans, using a Kestrel crooked knife to carve a mask.

These tools are used not just by creators of Northwest Coast art, but by people all over that make beautiful objects by hand.  If I don't take over the business of making these tools, they will cease being made.  I don't want that to happen.  I want future generations of artists to be able to experience the pleasure of using these unique and particularly well made tools.  These tools are awesome.  I want them to live on forever.

Charlie carving the feast tray that is one of the rewards listed below.


Who am I?

I am Charlie Prince. I was born and raised in Seattle Washington. I have always had a love for the unique place in the world I’ve grown up in, as well as the art of the Native Peoples from this area. Since I was a small child I have been in awe of the Northwest Coast art that was all around me, from trips to the Burke museum to the beautiful totem poles downtown to staring at art while sitting on the ferries. All the while I was doing this, Gregg was busy crafting adzes and crooked knives to supply the very carvers whose work I marveled at.

What is my project?

For over a year now I have worked alongside Gregg, as his apprentice, learning the different aspects of toolmaking and all the processes that go into creating Kestrel Tools.  As of the beginning of this year we formed an LLC and became partners in the company.

We have agreed to work together as partners for two years, after which Gregg will hopefully get to go into semi-"retirement", though he has promised to be there to consult with me and help me if I need it (not to mention probably give me a hard time).

The first step is to buy into the inventory that is at Gregg's shop.  So far I've made a down payment of $6500.

Through Indiegogo, I'm asking for help in raising the rest of the inventory money, as well as the money I need to purchase many of the basic tools needed for this venture, $22,000. 

My project is to set up a new Kestrel shop space with equipment and materials.  That includes everything from steel, copper and wood to grinding belts, buffing compounds, leather, twine, and all the other essentials that go into making these tools.  I will also buy the key pieces of machinery needed with this money.  We have agreed to work together at his shop until I can reach this goal. 

I can't buy Gregg's shop itself (I wish!), its not for sale.   Since the beginning Gregg has worked out of his shop on his property, but that shop is also used for other projects that don’t involve Kestrel tool. It is the shop he and Irene use to keep their homestead up and running, and once he "retires" he will use it to make art and play around with projects.   

This money is not the end all be all of what I need.  I know that I am going to work like crazy to get the rest. I appreciate all and any help you can give me in this, the first part of my journey as a toolmaker.

 

What this money will buy

Tools I need (these are the basics as far as power tools go.  Other tooling will be acquired over time, and some will continue to be used at Gregg's shop.  Other tools, mainly smaller hand tools, I already own)-

  • Metal/wood bandsaw - $2000
  • Dust collection - $920
  • Disk/belt sander - $784
  • Drum/flap sander - $302
  • Burr King grinder - $3085
  • Baldor low rpm buffers(2) - $1845
  • Foredom rotary grinder - $540
  • Drill press - $426

Total - $9902

Inventory of raw materials and supplies  - $12,000

Grand total - $ 22,000

What do you get for helping out?

For over 30 years Kestrel Tool has been inspired by, and in turn has contributed to the art and culture of the Northwest Coast. Gregg, who has been the driving force behind Kestrel for its entire existence, is getting on in age and shouldn’t have to spend all day with his nose to the grindstone (quite literally!). By taking on the toolmaking, I aim to free up more time for Gregg to create and innovate in his art, which will benefit all of us who use his tools.

By giving through this campaign, you can help secure a future for Kestrel Tools.  We have come up with a selection of gifts to thank you for your contribution to this cause.

First off is a 8x10 print of the picture above, taken during the Kestrel pole raising.  A gift to symbolize the passing of the torch from one generation to the next, signed by Charlie and Gregg and worthy of framing.  We'll also send a thank you postcard, with a special surprise picture, to all contributors over $5.  Who doesn't like to get a postcard in the mail?

 Our friend, artist Barry Herem was kind enough to let us use a design of his, which we have emblazoned on an organic cotton T shirt, and on an etched glass coffee mug. Kestrel has used this image in the past in its Wolf Dancer art classes, an appropriate sentiment, since my larger dreams include reviving the NWC art classes in the future. 

 To us, continuing to use this design symbolizes that we are committed to carrying on the tradition of sharing knowledge and art.

In addition to these gifts we’ve made up a limited run of “carvers’ calipers”, which are hand crafted out of aluminum by yours truly. They are an amazing tool to have when making bowls and masks and things to gauge the thickness of the piece. We’re teaming this up with a nice maple and leather honing strop with the Kestrel logo burned onto the handle. This is a great reward if you (or someone you love) is a carver and cares about Kestrel Tool!

And if you're not a carver yet, our "Get Carving"-reward might just get you started on becoming one. Get your hands on our C-bend, the most versatile of our knives and our Sitka gutter adze and we'll even throw in a sharpening stone and some literature to get you going.

That’s not all, either. I’ll be carving a series of ladles out of alder and cherry, for a nice piece of functional artwork in the style of the Northwest Coast. Hand carved by me using, you guessed it, Kestrel Tools! 

  As a special thank you for someone, I’m working on a Tlingit Style feast tray, of alder, which am detailing with a formline hawk design on each end.  I hope someone will be happy to set their table with it.


  And To top it all off, we’re offering a weekend carving class for up to 12 people, right here at the Kestrel shop. It’ll be like the Wolf Dancer classes of the past. This will be a NWC canoe-form bowl carving class, but advanced carvers should feel free to bring the project of their choice.  We're really excited about this one!

We've chosen the weekend of September 19, 20, 21 for the three day weekend of carving. Potluck first night, we make dinner on Saturday night, and we provide the alder for you to carve. Camping if you like, or you could find yourself a B&B or something like that.  We'll even provide the dog!  This is gonna be a lot of fun!

We'd like to thank all of the artists that have made this all possible.  

Please share this with anyone and everyone you think might be interested!  

Thank you so Much!!!  -  Charlie and Milla

I can't buy Gregg's shop itself (I wish!), its not for sale.   Since the beginning Gregg has worked out of his shop on his property, but that shop is also used for other projects that don’t involve Kestrel tool. It is the shop he and Irene use to keep their homestead up and running, and once he "retires" he will use it to make art and play around with projects.   




This money is not the end all be all of what I need.  I know that I am going to work like crazy to get the rest. I appreciate all and any help you can give me in this, the first part of my journey as a toolmaker. 
What this money will buy
Tools I need (these are the basics as far as power tools go.  Other tooling will be acquired over time, and some will continue to be used at Gregg's shop.  Other tools, mainly smaller hand tools, I already own)-

Metal/wood bandsaw - $2000
Dust collection - $920
Disk/belt sander - $784
Drum/flap sander - $302
Burr King grinder - $3085
Baldor low rpm buffers(2) - $1845
Foredom rotary grinder - $540
Drill press - $426

Total - $9902
Inventory of raw materials and supplies  - $12,000
Grand total - $ 22,000

What do you get for helping out?
For over 30 years Kestrel Tool has been inspired by, and in turn has contributed to the art and culture of the Northwest Coast. Gregg, who has been the driving force behind Kestrel for its entire existence, is getting on in age and shouldn’t have to spend all day with his nose to the grindstone (quite literally!). By taking on the toolmaking, I aim to free up more time for Gregg to create and innovate in his art, which will benefit all of us who use his tools.
By giving through this campaign, you can help secure a future for Kestrel Tools.  We have come up with a selection of gifts to thank you for your contribution to this cause.




First off is a 8x10 print of the picture above, taken during the Kestrel pole raising.  A gift to symbolize the passing of the torch from one generation to the next, signed by Charlie and Gregg and worthy of framing.  We'll also send a thank you postcard, with a special surprise picture, to all contributors over $5.  Who doesn't like to get a postcard in the mail?




 Our friend, artist Barry Herem was kind enough to let us use a design of his, which we have emblazoned on an organic cotton T shirt, and on an etched glass coffee mug. Kestrel has used this image in the past in its Wolf Dancer art classes, an appropriate sentiment, since my larger dreams include reviving the NWC art classes in the future. 




 To us, continuing to use this design symbolizes that we are committed to carrying on the tradition of sharing knowledge and art.




In addition to these gifts we’ve made up a limited run of “carvers’ calipers”, which are hand crafted out of aluminum by yours truly. They are an amazing tool to have when making bowls and masks and things to gauge the thickness of the piece. We’re teaming this up with a nice maple and leather honing strop with the Kestrel logo burned onto the handle. This is a great reward if you (or someone you love) is a carver and cares about Kestrel Tool!




And if you're not a carver yet, our "Get Carving"-reward might just get you started on becoming one. Get your hands on our C-bend, the most versatile of our knives and our Sitka gutter adze and we'll even throw in a sharpening stone and some literature to get you going.
That’s not all, either. I’ll be carving a series of ladles out of alder and cherry, for a nice piece of functional artwork in the style of the Northwest Coast. Hand carved by me using, you guessed it, Kestrel Tools! 




  As a special thank you for someone, I’m working on a Tlingit Style feast tray, of alder, which am detailing with a formline hawk design on each end.  I hope someone will be happy to set their table with it.



  And To top it all off, we’re offering a weekend carving class for up to 12 people, right here at the Kestrel shop. It’ll be like the Wolf Dancer classes of the past. This will be a NWC canoe-form bowl carving class, but advanced carvers should feel free to bring the project of their choice.  We're really excited about this one!

We've chosen the weekend of September 19, 20, 21 for the three day weekend of carving. Potluck first night, we make dinner on Saturday night, and we provide the alder for you to carve. Camping if you like, or you could find yourself a B&B or something like that.  We'll even provide the dog!  This is gonna be a lot of fun!We'd like to thank all of the artists that have made this all possible.  
Please share this with anyone and everyone you think might be interested!  
Thank you so Much!!!  -  Charlie and Milla

story:
The OMG Project

OMG Canvas is not just a regular canvas printing company. We create custom artwork. We want to brighten up the community by allowing local artists to showcase their work, their passion, and their talents to the world when they can't afford to put them in a gallery. What better way than to use the World Wide Web?

Every two months, we hand select four artists to showcase their art pieces on the OMG Canvas homepage. From there, interested buyers will be able to purchase unique canvas pieces in many different sizes to support their local artist.
Our motto is simple:

Our company aims to facilitate the encouragement of creative expression with the launch of our "the omg project" campaign (one must give). For every canvas sold, we'll be donating art supplies to various organizations, schools, and hospitals.

In addition, all of our products are made 100% in the USA from our canvas rolls, frames, and even our shipping boxes. We believe in supporting the wonderful country that we live, work and play in.

 

With your funding, we will...

With this funding, OMG Canvas would create a robust website. We want our website to be fun, friendly and quirky. Something that shows a bit of character, just like our artists. The OMG Canvas website is the next step in the right direction for us to help make these local artists' dreams come true. Right now we are currently helping out local artists only. With our formula, we believe we can do that with an appealing website.

Helping the art community, one canvas at a time!

Beautiful art piece to compliment your enviroment. 

An empty wall screams to be dressed by OMG Canvas. We offer one-of-a-kind art pieces made to dress any home, nursery, office or treehouse.

We also have the "East Meets West" edition pieces that have gained big traction here locally.  The "East Meets West" has a unique formula = an Asian Zodiac symbol + an American Horoscope symbol. Many parents of newborns have been contacting OMG Canvas for the "East Meets West" pieces customized for their newest bundle of joy. 

 

Each canvas sold brings us closer to our goals. If you can't help us by donating but are still interested in helping, you can share our campaign with friends, coworkers, and family.
