story:
www.artcrasher.com

What is Art Crasher?

Art Crasher is all about YOU, the artist. Art Crasher promotes and exposes new and upcoming artists on artcrasher.com. Each month Art Crasher has an online art show which features five galleries on the site. The five galleries are "Photography", "Visual/Painting", "Off the Canvas (installation art)", "Video" and "Street Art" (coming in November 2012). 

Art Crasher also includes interviews with more established artists and "Spotlight". The interviews provide advice for new artists and let them know how to get a foot into the art world and how to gain more exposure. Art Crasher places one artist in the "Spotlight" each month. The "Spotlight" features an interview and solo gallery of 20-30 pieces.  

Where does Art Crasher stand now?

Art Crasher receives an average of 400 entries for its online art show each month! From Australia to Berlin and all across the US, Art Crasher has received great reception on the international stage! After only two months of being online, Art Crasher gets an average of 200-300 hits a day.

Why does Art and Art Crasher matter? What are Art Crasher's goals?

In the US and countries around the world, art programs are being cut from school budgets and is slowly being seen as a "non-essential" subject. The University of Michigan says "The attempt at cutting funding for arts education stems all the way from the federal level...the federal government has proposed to make a cut of 35.6 million dollars in art education." We need Art in our schools because :

-the arts are needed by our young people as a forum for safe expression, communication, exploration, imagination, and cultural and historical understanding. 

-Brain research confirms that Arts education strengthens student problem-solving and critical thinking skills, adding to overall academic achievement, school success, and preparation for the work world. 

- Art classes provide students a chance to develop cognitive and creative skills, and to develop their imaginations.

Outside of school, Art still matters. Art knows no boundaries. It touches people of all ages and is a universal language that speaks to everyone. Here are a few important reasons why Art matters to everyone! As one art blog expresses (http://speakartloud.wordpress.com/) :

-Art is a Natural Human Behavior: Creating art is a primal behavior. Like language and laughter, art is a fundamental human behavior. Put very simply, art is a part of who we are.  We need art because it makes us complete human beings.

-Art is Communication: Art, like language, is a medium to express ideas and to share information. Art offers us a method to communicate what we may not necessarily fully understand or know how to express. Art helps us to share thoughts, ideas and visions that may not be able to be articulated any other way. We need art to have a full range of expression.

-Art is Healing: Creating or experiencing art can relax and sooth us or it may enliven and stimulate us. The process of creating art engages both the body and the mind and provides us with time to look inward and reflect. 

- Art Tells Our Story: Art is a history lesson, an historical record, a preservation of culture, and an autobiography all in one.  Art documents events and experiences and allows us a richer understanding of history. Art reflects cultural values, beliefs and identity and helps to preserve the many different communities that make up our world. Art chronicles our own lives and experiences over time. We need art to understand and to share our individual and shared history.

-Art is a Shared Experience: The creation of art is a collective activity.Even the solitary painter or poet relies upon the craft of the paint-maker or book-binder to help create art. Art offers us a reason to come together and share in an experience. We need art to keep us connected.

By keeping a strong online presence, not only is Art Crasher achieving its goal of promoting new artists, but its also working towards its goal of keeping Art alive and well.  

Why does Art Crasher need funding?

I'm an artist with no fancy tech skills.To keep Art Crasher going and growing, I need a web developer. To get a web developer I need funding.Web developers don't come cheap. Art Crasher will also be developing a small scale ad campaign to generate even more traffic and exposure. All funding will go towards a web developer and ad campaign.

story:
Short Summary

Our stretch goal, at the $800 mark, is this sexy Cesare card! 

As a trading card publisher, I've used my relationships in the comic book industry (I've been a historian and journalist for twenty years) to create indie card sets using Mike Allred's Madman (in 3D!) and G-Men from Hell; the toy line Amazing Heroes, the silent film Nosferatu, and my own comics history set Four Color. I love trading cards and am doing my darnedest to fill the void the major companies aren't looking to. With my Nosferatu card set, I donated several extra packs to a local movie house here in Richmond, The Bijou; I plan on doing the same with Caligari.

What We Need & What You Get

$13 gets you the 13-card Caligari set, while $23 gets you the cards plus a limited-to-Indie GoGo metal card (image of which is below). My creative goal with this set (I set a different one each card set I do) is to design a silent film card set that is not only reflective of silent film, but also Caligari's unique Expressionist aesthetic.

My higher levels include a combination set with the limited Nosferatu run, and even a full level that includes all of the cards I've published. There's even a level to get your own "silent film card" designed by myself and at a print run of 250.

The $500 covers both production for the limited print run of 250, as well as postage to send packs out to backers. I'm a sucker for stretch goals and have some in mind for when we push past the initial goal.

The Impact

This is not my first card set: I have an established and reliable printer and am determined to give nothing less than a quality trading card set in all my campaigns. You'll not only get this unique and limited way to relive the silent masterpiece of horror, but you'll also be part of a community of card lovers and collectors I call my friends.

Risks & Challenges

There are somethings that are as unforeseeable as a crazy somnambulist, such as freak weather, shipping mishaps, or corrupted image files. I've been through a few of those with my past campaigns and have always come out in the end. Since you will be producing this set with me, I will keep you up-to-date through both thick and thin.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this link through all social media for any fans of horror, movies, trading cards, and silent film! Also, check out my website and store to get a better look at what has come before.

story:
Who am I?

My name is Chrystal Powell. I am a metal art jeweler currently residing in San Francisco. I hold a a BFA in sculpture from AAU and am the mother of a 10 month old incredibly cute baby named River. Enfolding the idea that jewelry can fulfill roles beyond that of adornment, I use precious metals, natural minerals, and otherworldly allusions to construct pieces that are intended to serve the wearer; function as fashion accoutrements, wearable sculptures and objects of power.

Due to the need for more space, and a job change for my partner and child’s father- our family is relocating from San Francisco to Petaluma this Winter. I have collected many tools over the years, but I do not currently own the vast majority of the tools and pieces of equipment I use on a daily basis.

It is my goal to raise $6,000 to directly fund the acquisition of tools and equipment to outfit a metal-shop that will secure my ability to make my work and to teach my craft to others. Most of these tools will last beyond the entirety of my lifetime. You can help make this happen and get fine handcrafted jewelry  in the process!

The tools will equip me with the long-term capacity to create from an operable, organized shop. I will be enabled to use standard production procedures to efficiently create works of wearable art- and be afforded the opportunity to pursue this craft as a business that will support my family. I would greatly appreciate your support at this time.

What this campaign is about and why it’s important to me: 

 For the past decade, I’ve worked in collective studio spaces, alongside uncountable gifted artists and craftspeople who also make jewelry and sculpture. These spaces have been operable, due to vast and shared resources. It’s been a gift to work in communities like these; hubs harboring tools, skill-shares and constructive feedback. I am beyond grateful for these experiences- but feel it is essential to my craft and work that I create a functioning studio of my own- proximal to my home, where I can focus on my work with tools and equipment that are organized, available and in well working order.

This campaign is an effort to get a shop setup in our new town and residence where I can resume creative and business operations without a gigantic pause caused by the need to raise funds in some other way. You get handmade fine art jewelry, I'll get to keep working, we all win!

My History:

Early last year, I was living in the basement of a 16 person live/work arts collective in the Mission District of San Francisco, Million Fishes. Months before, I had quit my 10 year long stint as a waitress and bartender to focus solely on developing my artistic craft, and to pour my efforts into growing this craft into a sustainable business. I balanced my earnings from art jewelry sales, with teaching classes and workshops in metal-smithing to adults and middle school aged kids.

Things were working. My business goals were set and I was on the road to acheiving them, when I became pregnant with my first child. Motherhood, among all of its hormonal, physical and mental shiftings, has deeply transformed my focus and vision for my artwork. I have never felt more clear and committed to the power and possibility that is the metal art jewelry I make.
As the birth of my son let me in to the understanding of my power as a woman, I have also been overtaken with passion, commitment and clarity to the power of my artwork. It is my goal to move forward with a comprehensive business plan ( that was put on hold for River's incubation and arrival), that will allow me to support our family with my craft. 
I want my son to learn that success is possible and probable in the world when a person aligns themselves with what they come to understand as "their work." The wearable sculpture that I make, is "my work" in the world. I am asking for your support to continue on my quest in its development and potential for its reach, while enabling me to support my family financially, physically and emotionally.

The magnitude of what you can help me achieve is immeasurable:

One person can make small things happen- I have always practiced and believed that with the support of community- the dreams of many can grow exponentially. I am turning to you- my community and yours too- to help me grow my dreams at this turning point in my life and practice.

Here are a few ways in which your contribution will impact my work:

  • In ten minutes, I can cause fabricated edges of a hollow form to meet with a belt sander; a process I can finish by hand in over an hour.
  • With a rolling mill, I can recycle my scrap metal into plates and wires from which I can create new work.
  • With a rolling mill, I can create veins of texture on wings, experiment and imprint imagery sourced from my own etchings onto metal, in minutes.
  • With a tumbler, I can clean 30 silver hummingbird castings in 30 minutes- a process that would take me 3 full days of work.
  • With a buffing machine, I can efficiently polish and finish pieces in minutes, that would otherwise require hours and hours of labor to take to a finished level- understanding that the level of finishing I'm interested in just wouldn't be possible with out this machine.
  • With dapping blocks and anvils, I can create the bulbous, organic and hollow forms I work to construct efficiently- these are necessary and vital tools for these processes.

My work will thrive in a studio where I can choose from correct tools to do the correct job- rather than spending valuable time reinventing my process and pieces so that I can create with the small amount of tools I currently own.

Essentially: Outfitting my shop with these tools will allow me to move forward in my practice. I will keep creating, teaching and walking down the path of the artist, while being able to support my family.

What I Need

The Breakdown:
Electrical equipment for preparing, polishing and finishing metal; hand tools to form, move and secure metal; and tools for precision fabrication and soldering:

ELECTRICAL– $1,613
Polisher/buffer (Baldor) Dust collector, bowl tumbler, Grizzly belt/disc sander

HAND TOOLS- $2,080
engraver's block, rolling mill, ring reducer/stretcher/englarer, wire gauges, chasing tools, dapping set, ring mandrel, oval bracelet, round bracelet
steel block, necklace mandrel, hoop mandrel, bezel mandrel, 100lb anvil

SOLDERING/PRECISION/PRODUCTION- $2,307
Micro Minismith, finger gauge, 1propane tank, 1 oxygen tank, tripod, charcoal blocks, third hand- 2, pickle+pot, optivisor, diamond grinder glass saw, tube cutter, sinusoidal stake 4", round disc cutter, miter-cutting vise


Totaling: $6,000

These tools and pieces of equipment will allow me to create using the standard production procedures with which I currently teach and practice.

Any funds that either exceed my goal or are leftover from finding tools on sale/used in great working condition, I will use to purchase raw materials such as sterling silver and rubber mold material to produce my upcoming limited production line of jewelry. 

My many years experience in production houses, private studios and learning institutions informs my understanding for how to outfit and operate a full shop. I appreciate your help in making this happen!

Here’s the fun part. What You Get:

Jewelry! Exclusive Jewelry! Hand crafted fine jewelry! Personalized-one-of-a-kind room stopping jewelry.

Seriously! Have you always wanted a pair of my hummingbird earrings but haven’t been able to justify/afford the expense? Need some affirmation bracelets to remind you of how beautiful you are in the morning? Would you like to use this opportunity to start working on a one-of-a-kind custom piece with me? Brush up your own soldering skills or learn how to etch? I have fantastic things to offer you for your contribution. Please donate today!

  • For a $40 donation, I’ll make you a pair of earrings with a laminated high resolution photograph printed on archival paper hanging from handmade sterling silver earring findings! Handcrafted- original wearable artwork. Choose from the image of flying or stationary birds
  • .Magical minerals enclosed in a glass vile with sterling silver oxidized cap and chain. $50 Choose from garnet, kyanite, black tourmaline or amethyst.
  • Bird on a wire- Plant stick/hair stick. 1 bronze bird on a hammered nickel silver long stem. Perfect hair sticks or planter decor. $75
  • $125- Sterling silver hammered spiral earrings. Can be made for regular sized pierced ears or slightly gauged holes. 
  • For $150 I will make you two (TWO!) brass bangles with whatever-you-want stamped on them. Affirmations? A special quote? Daily reminder? Love notes? Limit to 7 words per bracelet.
  • $175- One 4 hours private metal-smithing lesson to be conducted in Petaluma once the shop is up and running. Projected date: March 2013. Beginning or advanced techniques can be covered. Please inquire for questions or extra details.
  • Wait? You CAN afford those earrings now? Great! Perfect timing for us both to get something of serious use and lasting value. Gift them, wear them, hang them above your plants for donating $200. These are limited editions- and the last of my birds are almost completely gone! Bronze with sterling silver chain and earwires.
  • Eyeball rings? Choose your size. Sterling silver and brass. $225
  • A friend once told me- "every woman needs a locket. " These are one-of-a-kind hand crafted, fabricated lockets, individually made and there is a very nice weight to them.  I will even fill it with my home-crafted magical cure-all lavender-calendula-lemon balm salve if you like. Please keep in mind- due to the nature of one-of-kind pieces, yours will vary from the photograph. If you have specific requests around chain length or otherwise, just msg me!  $400 (does not include bird as reflected in photograph)
  • $400- Square tarot locket. If you prefer- you can send me a photograph or illustration of some other sort and I can laminate it and set it behind the glass (instead of the tarot card). Choose your card!
  • For $500- I will work with you to make a custom ring or necklace. Involving an initial consultation, secondary meeting with sketches and/or moquettes and a final, personal, original wearable art piece. Materials not to exceed $50. Projected fabrication hours not to exceed 10. If you have your own gold (or other materials) and would like to incorporate this into your piece, I am more than happy to work with you/it! If projected hours exceed 10hrs- we can discuss minimizing the scope of the piece or the option to pay a $30/hourly surcharge.
  •   For $1000- I will work with you to make a complex custom ring or necklace. Involving an initial consultation, secondary meeting with sketches and/or moquettes and a final, personal, original wearable art piece. Materials not to exceed $50. Projected fabrication hours not to exceed 20. If you have your own gold (or other materials) and would like to incorporate this into your piece, I am more than happy to work with you/it! If projected hours exceed 20- we can discuss minimizing the scope of the piece or the option to pay a $30/hourly surcharge.

Due to the very reason for this fundraiser- (Moving!) I will be making perks on a first come first serve basis. The perks relating to the first $1000 in contributions will be make by mid December. The perks relating to the donations to follow the initial $1000 can be expected in early March 2014, as I will need a small window of time to purchase tools and setup my new studio to make the pieces. If you can donate and find your perks to be in this time-frame, but want or need your perk sooner than March- please just msg me and I will do whatever I can to accommodate your desires!

  If I don't reach my goal- this campaign will still be funded- but Indiegogo will take and extra 5%  of the funds. Please help me reach this goal in its entirety! I am endlessly grateful for you and your support and looking so much forward to this next step in my jewelry work and life.Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!



Other Ways You Can Help
If you are moved to support me but can't do so financially, you can still help! Post this fundraiser to all your social networking channels, send emails to your loved ones who you think would connect to my work. I have 45 days to make this happen, and need your support in getting the word out! Facebook! Twitter! Lists!

This campaign is an effort to get a shop setup in our new town and residence where I can resume creative and business operations without a gigantic pause caused by the need to raise funds in some other way. You get handmade fine art jewelry, I'll get to keep working, we all win!
My History: 

Early last year, I was living in the basement of a 16 person live/work arts collective in the Mission District of San Francisco, Million Fishes. Months before, I had quit my 10 year long stint as a waitress and bartender to focus solely on developing my artistic craft, and to pour my efforts into growing this craft into a sustainable business. I balanced my earnings from art jewelry sales, with teaching classes and workshops in metal-smithing to adults and middle school aged kids. 
Things were working. My business goals were set and I was on the road to acheiving them, when I became pregnant with my first child. Motherhood, among all of its hormonal, physical and mental shiftings, has deeply transformed my focus and vision for my artwork. I have never felt more clear and committed to the power and possibility that is the metal art jewelry I make.As the birth of my son let me in to the understanding of my power as a woman, I have also been overtaken with passion, commitment and clarity to the power of my artwork. It is my goal to move forward with a comprehensive business plan ( that was put on hold for River's incubation and arrival), that will allow me to support our family with my craft.  I want my son to learn that success is possible and probable in the world when a person aligns themselves with what they come to understand as "their work." The wearable sculpture that I make, is "my work" in the world. I am asking for your support to continue on my quest in its development and potential for its reach, while enabling me to support my family financially, physically and emotionally.
The magnitude of what you can help me achieve is immeasurable: 
One person can make small things happen- I have always practiced and believed that with the support of community- the dreams of many can grow exponentially. I am turning to you- my community and yours too- to help me grow my dreams at this turning point in my life and practice. Here are a few ways in which your contribution will impact my work: 
In ten minutes, I can cause fabricated edges of a hollow form to meet with a belt sander; a process I can finish by hand in over an hour. 
With a rolling mill, I can recycle my scrap metal into plates and wires from which I can create new work.

With a rolling mill, I can create veins of texture on wings, experiment and imprint imagery sourced from my own etchings onto metal, in minutes. 
With a tumbler, I can clean 30 silver hummingbird castings in 30 minutes- a process that would take me 3 full days of work.


With a buffing machine, I can efficiently polish and finish pieces in minutes, that would otherwise require hours and hours of labor to take to a finished level- understanding that the level of finishing I'm interested in just wouldn't be possible with out this machine. 

With dapping blocks and anvils, I can create the bulbous, organic and hollow forms I work to construct efficiently- these are necessary and vital tools for these processes.


My work will thrive in a studio where I can choose from correct tools to do the correct job- rather than spending valuable time reinventing my process and pieces so that I can create with the small amount of tools I currently own.
Essentially: Outfitting my shop with these tools will allow me to move forward in my practice. I will keep creating, teaching and walking down the path of the artist, while being able to support my family.
What I Need 
The Breakdown:Electrical equipment for preparing, polishing and finishing metal; hand tools to form, move and secure metal; and tools for precision fabrication and soldering: ELECTRICAL– $1,613Polisher/buffer (Baldor) Dust collector, bowl tumbler, Grizzly belt/disc sanderHAND TOOLS- $2,080engraver's block, rolling mill, ring reducer/stretcher/englarer, wire gauges, chasing tools, dapping set, ring mandrel, oval bracelet, round braceletsteel block, necklace mandrel, hoop mandrel, bezel mandrel, 100lb anvilSOLDERING/PRECISION/PRODUCTION- $2,307Micro Minismith, finger gauge, 1propane tank, 1 oxygen tank, tripod, charcoal blocks, third hand- 2, pickle+pot, optivisor, diamond grinder glass saw, tube cutter, sinusoidal stake 4", round disc cutter, miter-cutting vise
Totaling: $6,000These tools and pieces of equipment will allow me to create using the standard production procedures with which I currently teach and practice.Any funds that either exceed my goal or are leftover from finding tools on sale/used in great working condition, I will use to purchase raw materials such as sterling silver and rubber mold material to produce my upcoming limited production line of jewelry.  
My many years experience in production houses, private studios and learning institutions informs my understanding for how to outfit and operate a full shop. I appreciate your help in making this happen!
Here’s the fun part. What You Get:
Jewelry! Exclusive Jewelry! Hand crafted fine jewelry! Personalized-one-of-a-kind room stopping jewelry. Seriously! Have you always wanted a pair of my hummingbird earrings but haven’t been able to justify/afford the expense? Need some affirmation bracelets to remind you of how beautiful you are in the morning? Would you like to use this opportunity to start working on a one-of-a-kind custom piece with me? Brush up your own soldering skills or learn how to etch? I have fantastic things to offer you for your contribution. Please donate today! 
For a $40 donation, I’ll make you a pair of earrings with a laminated high resolution photograph printed on archival paper hanging from handmade sterling silver earring findings! Handcrafted- original wearable artwork. Choose from the image of flying or stationary birds
.Magical minerals enclosed in a glass vile with sterling silver oxidized cap and chain. $50 Choose from garnet, kyanite, black tourmaline or amethyst.
Bird on a wire- Plant stick/hair stick. 1 bronze bird on a hammered nickel silver long stem. Perfect hair sticks or planter decor. $75
$125- Sterling silver hammered spiral earrings. Can be made for regular sized pierced ears or slightly gauged holes. 
For $150 I will make you two (TWO!) brass bangles with whatever-you-want stamped on them. Affirmations? A special quote? Daily reminder? Love notes? Limit to 7 words per bracelet.
$175- One 4 hours private metal-smithing lesson to be conducted in Petaluma once the shop is up and running. Projected date: March 2013. Beginning or advanced techniques can be covered. Please inquire for questions or extra details.
Wait? You CAN afford those earrings now? Great! Perfect timing for us both to get something of serious use and lasting value. Gift them, wear them, hang them above your plants for donating $200. These are limited editions- and the last of my birds are almost completely gone! Bronze with sterling silver chain and earwires.
Eyeball rings? Choose your size. Sterling silver and brass. $225
A friend once told me- "every woman needs a locket. " These are one-of-a-kind hand crafted, fabricated lockets, individually made and there is a very nice weight to them.  I will even fill it with my home-crafted magical cure-all lavender-calendula-lemon balm salve if you like. Please keep in mind- due to the nature of one-of-kind pieces, yours will vary from the photograph. If you have specific requests around chain length or otherwise, just msg me!  $400 (does not include bird as reflected in photograph)
$400- Square tarot locket. If you prefer- you can send me a photograph or illustration of some other sort and I can laminate it and set it behind the glass (instead of the tarot card). Choose your card!
For $500- I will work with you to make a custom ring or necklace. Involving an initial consultation, secondary meeting with sketches and/or moquettes and a final, personal, original wearable art piece. Materials not to exceed $50. Projected fabrication hours not to exceed 10. If you have your own gold (or other materials) and would like to incorporate this into your piece, I am more than happy to work with you/it! If projected hours exceed 10hrs- we can discuss minimizing the scope of the piece or the option to pay a $30/hourly surcharge.
  For $1000- I will work with you to make a complex custom ring or necklace. Involving an initial consultation, secondary meeting with sketches and/or moquettes and a final, personal, original wearable art piece. Materials not to exceed $50. Projected fabrication hours not to exceed 20. If you have your own gold (or other materials) and would like to incorporate this into your piece, I am more than happy to work with you/it! If projected hours exceed 20- we can discuss minimizing the scope of the piece or the option to pay a $30/hourly surcharge. 


Due to the very reason for this fundraiser- (Moving!) I will be making perks on a first come first serve basis. The perks relating to the first $1000 in contributions will be make by mid December. The perks relating to the donations to follow the initial $1000 can be expected in early March 2014, as I will need a small window of time to purchase tools and setup my new studio to make the pieces. If you can donate and find your perks to be in this time-frame, but want or need your perk sooner than March- please just msg me and I will do whatever I can to accommodate your desires!  If I don't reach my goal- this campaign will still be funded- but Indiegogo will take and extra 5%  of the funds. Please help me reach this goal in its entirety! I am endlessly grateful for you and your support and looking so much forward to this next step in my jewelry work and life.Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are moved to support me but can't do so financially, you can still help! Post this fundraiser to all your social networking channels, send emails to your loved ones who you think would connect to my work. I have 45 days to make this happen, and need your support in getting the word out! Facebook! Twitter! Lists!

story:
Painting Happier, Healthier Communities

The Nicaragua Mural Project is the first project by the Abel Arts Collective, a nonprofit (501(c)3 status in the works!) that partners with artists, developmental organizations and communities to create meaningful and inspirational public art projects. 

We believe everyone should have the opportunity to create and experience art, especially youth. We think art allows people to express themselves and can make people happier and healthier. We think public art has the ability to transform a space and positively impact a community. 

For our first project, we're traveling to Gigante, a small village in Nicaragua, to create a mural with the local youth group and Health Committee on the newly constructed Community Health Center. Our partner nonprofit, Project WOO, has led the Health Committee in developing the Center after a community census in Gigante identified access to community health as the village's biggest need. 

Until now, the closest clinic was 15 kilometers away. A doctor comes to visit the village every 2 weeks, seeing patients in a church with less than adequate conditions. The community was in need of their own clinic that offered privacy, running water, electricity, and comfort. 

The Gigante Health Committee wants the Center to be bright and happy, encouraging locals to get the access to the health services and education they need in an inviting atmosphere. We will concept the mural with the local youth group, people of Gigante and our partners before inviting all to participate in the painting of the mural. Our goal is to create something meaningful for the community with the community, something we hope strengthens the success of the Center. 

Very Perky! Paintings, Prints & More

The great thing about creating an art campaign is we have A LOT of amazing art as perks! Prints, original paintings, and eco-friendly iPhone cases.  All art by Erik Abel. 

  • $40 - Tru Protection Eco-friendly iPhone Cover (Your choice! Fits i4/4s/5)
  • $60 - Any one newly released fine art print 18x24" (Your choice!) $150 for the set of all 3 or $100 - for the set of all 3 as 12x16" matted prints 
  • $100 - Any 1 of the 24x36" prints (Your choice!)
  • $400 - Fish Outta Water 041, 042, OR 043 Original Painting on Sector 9 Skateboard. Ready to hang!
  • $800 - Fish Outta Water 037 Original Painting on Plywood. Ready to hang!
  • $850 - Fish Outta Water 038 Original Painting on Plywood. Ready to hang!
  • $1050 - Fish Outta Water 039 OR 040 Original Painting on Wood Panel 

We will email you after you make your contribution so you can tell us which designs you want!

Where Your $$ Goes 

We are raising $5000 to cover the cost of our trip. This will cover our art supplies (paint, paint brushes, tarps, tape, buckets, etc) and the cost of our travel to/from Nicaragua and lodging it Gigante. 

Additional funds raised will be donated between nonprofits: 

  • Project Woo and Surf for Life to support their existing and upcoming development projects in Central America (half of extra funds raised after our goal)
  • Abel Arts Collective to support our next art development project (half of extra funds raised after goal)
 Our Story 

We started the Abel Arts Collective after working with several nonprofits to raise money for their humanitarian and environmental causes through donations from Erik Abel's art. While we loved giving back through donations, we wanted to pursue a more hands on project that was centered around the positive impacts art creates and find a way for other artists to do the same. So, we started our own organization that will allow people everywhere to experience the joy in creating art and the benefits public art offers to a community. This project in Nicaragua is our pilot, using Erik as our guinea pig to determine the best way to coordinate philanthropic art projects before bringing other artists in the future. 

We've partnered with Project WOO and Surf for Life, two merging nonprofits that work across Central America. These amazing organizations promote sustainable community development through the construction of educational and community centers. They work with local communities to address their greatest challenges and bring much needed services to underserved communities. 

Thank you and Other Ways to Help! 

Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about our Project! We're so excited to create something beautiful in such an important space. We're grateful to our partners, the people of Gigante, and YOU for helping us complete what we hope to be an incredible project that sets the stage for more in the near future! 

If you aren't in a place to financially contribute, please help us spread the word by sharing this video to your social media, sending to your friends, and letting other know! 

With all of our hearts, 

THANK YOU!!! 

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 

Larger Perk Images...

story:
Bref résumé

La Itable est une table inspiré de la beauté de l'italie. 

Le concept  de l'Itable est de construire cette table qui aurait la forme de l'Italie avec du bois et de manière écologique. La Itable aurait diverses fonction :

-table pour le café

-table pour l'apéro pour partager des moment conviviales entres amis

-table pour poser son ordinateur et pour travailler

               ou simplement pour décorer votre salon.

Peut être qu'elle pourrait séduire les amoureux de l'Italie.


Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

J'aurais besoin de meilleur matériaux pour améliorer la qualité de la table et pour y faire des améliorations. Ce que j'ai fait jusqu'à présent n'est qu'un prototype de taille réelle. Pour une participation de 150euros, vous pouvez acquérir la Itable. 

    L'impact

    Grace à vos participations au projet, la Itable pourra devenir encore plus agréable et belle à voir. La version finale devrait être incroyablement différente.

      Risques et défis 

      Les risques sont que peut être cette table sera trop petite ou ne conviendra pas au clients, il faudra alors  à ce moment adapter la table au désirs des participants.

        D'autres façons d'aider

        Si vous n'avez pas les moyens de participer au projet ou tout simplement pas envie d'y participer, vous pouvez bien évidement me laisser des commentaires sur le projet et des idées pour améliorer la Itable,toute idée sera la bienvenue. 

        Si le projet vous a plu et vous trouvez le concept intéressant, n’hésiter pas à en parler autour de vous.

Si le projet vous a plu et vous trouvez le concept intéressant, n’hésiter pas à en parler autour de vous.

story:
Photographs steal your soul, so we better make them good.
-Dirt Candy Photography

We love to shoot movie-inspired photographic scenes that have a cinematic feel. We love for our images to show the dirt and grit. We adore the Grindhouse 70s grime. We specialize in Horror and Macabre shoots.  We shoot all over town, but our main home is in a rundown old house with no Heat or AC and no running water. We know how to stretch our budget of about $25.00 per shoot to make our scenes look like they cost a lot more to create. We want to take things to the next level and begin including local models and actors into our sets. We want to make them more detailed and realistic. Dirt Candy is made up of two ladies who love to take creepy pictures, do all our own FX work, and create our own sets from scratch. We do not like to photoshop or alter our work. We keep it old school and create all our pieces. If we cannot make it, we will not do it.

We are currently planning a large shoot for www.biogamergirl.com magazine. The theme is Witchcraft and we plan to create our most detailed set and costuming to date, but we need your help. We do not receive any funding for the shoots for the magazine and all our props, makeup, and costumes are funded by us.

We are looking for a few bucks to help us score some new makeup and prop pieces to take this set to the next level. Since we have a large cast and require costuming we need your help. Help us make this set RAD!

The Impact

This shoot is a great opportunity to showcase local West Virginia talent and our love for horror and the macabre. West Virginia is one of the last places that people think about when it comes to creating horror based arts and films. If we do not receive additional funding we cannot take on such a large project. This photo set will feature 10 actors/actresses/models from West Virginia. For most of them it is their modeling debut. We are working with local people who love what we do and really want to be involved in the project. Without the additional funds we are going to struggle in making this a believable set.


What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $200.00, and anything beyond that will go toward making Dirt Candy even more awesome. This money will go into latex, blood, witchcraft props, and costuming. We will be creating/sewing them ourselves and creating 75% of the props.


If you decide to give us a helping hand we will be offering anyone who donates a 4x6 print from the shoot, a personal hand-written thank you, and a chance to receive an autographed prop from the shoot. Anyone who donates receives our gifts. We cannot offer much, but we definitely appreciate your help and love.


Other Ways You Can Help

Check us out at http://www.facebook.com/dirtcandyphotography or @dirtcandyphoto

Please friend and follow us! Check out our work, please. We love feedback!

story:
THE ARTIST


My name is Tara Tippett Artist and owner at Tara Seren Arts. I'm an illustrator who grew up in the small town of Carbondale, CO. I attended The Art Institute Of Colorado and was unable to finish due to financial circumstances  beyond my control. However I continued as an an artist and am pursuing it as my profession and lifestyle.  I currently reside in Golden Co along with my husband,  Van Fischer , and our two Toddlers,  Fawkes (5) and Rowan(3). Where I work as a freelance illustrator, Portrait artist and craftswoman, and My husband is employed in Digital Signage and is a freelance Animator.

I enjoy working on projects that range from children’s books and fantasy illustration, to realistic portraiture. I draw upon inspiration from my own life stories and inspirations, along with nature, mythology, folklore, and fairy tales, my artwork tends to take on an imaginative and dream world feeling, full of detail,  and with occasional modern elements.

Even more so I enjoy sharing my artwork with the world and that's what this campaign is about!

THE CAMPAIGN


RAW: Natural born Artists http://www.rawartists.org/taraseren recently invited me to participate in their June Showcase in Boulder on June 29th, 2013. The showcase is a single night event in Boulder, Co at the historic Absinthe House Venue! Where a selection of artists have the opportunity to showcase and sell their work without RAW taking any commission of the sales.

RAW is a independent arts organization, for artists, by artists, who encourage the creative success of the many visionaries and storytellers of our generation.


THE IMPACT & FUNDING NEEDS

Part of what makes art so valuable and so full of impact is its ability to speak to, and be experienced by a variety of people across all walks of life and even time.

The RAW initiative is funded by ticket sales, so for artists to participate they have to commit to selling 20 tickets to the show and that's where you come in. By supporting this campaign you are making it possible for me to participate in the show.

WHY $600?


To be in the show I have to sell 20 tickets or raise $300 in sponsorship, the remaining $300 will go towards framing for the artwork that will be in the show, Supplies to create Dream Catchers and Dream Catcher sculpture in works to show, We are asked to supply some of our own lighting and hanging hardware and tools.

WHAT'S IN IT FOR THE ARTIST?


RAW artists do not only get to join the showcase. They are also promoted on the RAW website, they receive a set of professional photos and a video with an interview to use for press releases after the show and also the opportunity to exhibit in one other US city later on. RAW also pulls in local talent scouts in the surrounding area. Its a huge Opportunity for some one like me. Thank YOU!

$5USD Hi-res digital wallpaper

$10USD Postcard Greetings 

$15USD Greeting Card 

$15USD RAW: Showcase Ticket 


$40 USD Limited Edition Print 


$50USD Digital  landscape



$45 USD 1 Dream Catcher

$100USD Digital Portrait


$150 USD Fantasy Digital Portrait 

$40 USD Copy of a book I illustrated 

$200USD An Original Drawing  an example of ..

$250USD Illustration commission example of...
story_txt:
THE ARTIST My name is Tara Tippett Artist and owner at Tara Seren Arts. I'm an illustrator who grew up in the small town of Carbondale, CO. I attended The Art Institute Of Colorado and was unable to finish due to financial circumstances  beyond my control. However I continued as an an artist and am pursuing it as my profession and lifestyle.  I currently reside in Golden Co along with my husband,  Van Fischer , and our two Toddlers,  Fawkes (5) and Rowan(3). Where I work as a freelance illustrator, Portrait artist and craftswoman, and My husband is employed in Digital Signage and is a freelance Animator.I enjoy working on projects that range from children’s books and fantasy illustration, to realistic portraiture. I draw upon inspiration from my own life stories and inspirations, along with nature, mythology, folklore, and fairy tales, my artwork tends to take on an imaginative and dream world feeling, full of detail,  and with occasional modern elements.Even more so I enjoy sharing my artwork with the world and that's what this campaign is about!THE CAMPAIGNRAW: Natural born Artists http://www.rawartists.org/taraseren recently invited me to participate in their June Showcase in Boulder on June 29th, 2013. The showcase is a single night event in Boulder, Co at the historic Absinthe House Venue! Where a selection of artists have the opportunity to showcase and sell their work without RAW taking any commission of the sales.RAW is a independent arts organization, for artists, by artists, who encourage the creative success of the many visionaries and storytellers of our generation.THE IMPACT & FUNDING NEEDSPart of what makes art so valuable and so full of impact is its ability to speak to, and be experienced by a variety of people across all walks of life and even time. The RAW initiative is funded by ticket sales, so for artists to participate they have to commit to selling 20 tickets to the show and that's where you come in. By supporting this campaign you are making it possible for me to participate in the show. WHY $600?To be in the show I have to sell 20 tickets or raise $300 in sponsorship, the remaining $300 will go towards framing for the artwork that will be in the show, Supplies to create Dream Catchers and Dream Catcher sculpture in works to show, We are asked to supply some of our own lighting and hanging hardware and tools.WHAT'S IN IT FOR THE ARTIST?RAW artists do not only get to join the showcase. They are also promoted on the RAW website, they receive a set of professional photos and a video with an interview to use for press releases after the show and also the opportunity to exhibit in one other US city later on. RAW also pulls in local talent scouts in the surrounding area. Its a huge Opportunity for some one like me. Thank YOU!$5USD Hi-res digital wallpaper 

$10USD Postcard Greetings $15USD Greeting Card $15USD RAW: Showcase Ticket $40 USD Limited Edition Print $50USD Digital  landscape

story:
About

Leaving: Tutorials on How & When is a hand-bound artist book by Tania De Rozario, housing the poem of the same name. It features:

  • French-folded pages, folded and bound by hand.
  • Reprinted illustrations by the artist, that run over folded edges.
  • A soft cover
  • A charm bookmark, bound into the spine of the book.

The full poem is previously unpublished in print, and can be found here, in case you want to know what you are getting into! :)


What You are Funding

What is unique about this campaign, is that most of the funding categories
simply involve you pre-ordering and paying for copies of the book - no more, no less. A single copy of the book costs $27, with the price decreasing the more copies you buy.

By supporting this project, the tangible costs you are funding include:

  • The physical materials of the book, such as paper, glue, string, charms, etc.
  • Bookbinding tools such as a bone folder, awl, cutter, etc.
  • The printing costs of the book.
  • The time it will take to hand-make 100 copies of the book.
  • Indiegogo's platform fees.
  • Postage (non-registered) of you book(s) to a selected address.
  • Postage Packaging.

Intangible elements you are funding include:

  • Supporting a creative initiative not bound to commercial or institutional support.
  • The ongoing confluences between art, literature and craft. 
  • Hand-made products purchased at the source.
  • The proliferation of this piece of writing beyond the scope of the internet and beyond the scope of mass production.


All funders will receive their books in November 2014.


Who Are You?

I am an artist, writer and curator based in Singapore. My first book of poetry, Tender Delirium, was published and released in 2013 by Math Paper Press. I run EtiquetteSG,  a multidisciplinary platform focused on developing and showcasing art, writing, film and music by women and was the 2011 recipient of Singapore's SPH-NAC Golden Point Award for English Poetry. I am also an Associate Artist with The Substation, Singapore's first independent contemporary arts centre supporting research and innovation; my visual work has been showcased in Singapore, London, San Francisco, Amsterdam and Spain. You can check out more of my work at www.TaniaDeRozario.com.


But Have You Made Artist Books Before?

Yes, I have created a number of hand-made books, the most prominent one being The Shortest Distance, a 100-edition artist book launched in 2007. The book featured French-fold pages, running borders and a fully-functional,  string-tied wrap-around cover made from existing envelopes.

All copies of the book have since been sold or pre-ordered. 

Photos by Han, courtesy of Octopus Ink.

story:
Scala Contarini del Bovolo, the hidden treasure of Venice

The spiral staircase most fascinating of Venice is closed to the public for about 10 years. 

Everything is ready for it’s reopening, help us to cross the finish line with a donation.

Fondazione Venezia – Servizi alla Persona, in collaboration with the IRE of Venice, will analyze the request for access to the museum site to evaluate their interest in the world's population.

With your contribution, you will help the Foundation to accomplish its goals:

  • Reopening to the public of the Scala Contarini del Bovolo
  • Establishing educational and cultural lectures in schools given by experts and guided tours within the structures
  • Restoration of the frescoes and paintings owned by the Palazzo Contarini

After the completion of the last restoration, the Scala Contarini del Bovolo is now ready to reopen its doors to the city and to be reinserted into the urban context.

With a donation to our mission, you contribute to give humanity a chance to visit a monument.

Its heart will beat again thanks to the reunion with its audience.

What We Need & What You Get

Fondazione Venezia – Servizi alla Persona needs your contribution to complete the project for reopening the Scala Contarini del Bovolo and the areas around it to the public, and to achieve other goals such as the cultural/educational project which aims to raise awareness about the beauty of the Scala Contarini to children and young people, through several lectures in the schools of Venice given by our experts and the recovery of other artistic and cultural property of the IRE and their restitution to the community. 

We set a goal of 55,000 $ but any amount donated will contribute to achieve our objective.  For this reason, we want to thank you concretely with a reward, whatever amount you will give to us even a minimum donation can make a difference.

If you cannot make a donation, there is another way you can contribute to our cause, share this campaign on your Facebook page and Twitter, in this way you will help us spread our initiative!

Rewards for donations

We cannot thank you enough for your support, you will always be part of our project and to prove it, we have thought of awards that can go along with our heartfelt thanks.

  • E-mail expressing our gratitude with a digital postcard of the Scala del Bovolo
  • Single ticket for standard tour + e-mail expressing our gratitude with a digital postcard of the Scala del Bovolo
  • Printed image of the Scala del Bovolo
  • Two tickets for standard tour + e-mail expressing our gratitude with a digital postcard of the Scala del Bovolo
  • Single ticket with private guided tour (by appointment only)
  • Group ticket (up to 5 people) with private guided tour (by appointment only)
  • Group ticket (up to 10 people) with private guided tour (by appointment only)
  • Group ticket (up to 5 people) with private guided tour at closing time (by appointment only)
  • Group ticket (up to 10 people) with private guided tour at closing time (by appointment only)
  • Printed image of the Scala del Bovolo on canvas, limited edition
  • Cocktail in Belvedere by appointment (until 5 people)
  • Cocktail in Belvedere by appointment (until 10 people)
  • Photo service (wedding or anniversary by appointment) at closing time
  • Invitation to the Opening

Social Commitment & Art: an inseparable duo

Fondazione Venezia – Servizi alla Persona was founded in 2014 as an institution that provides welfare services, and has as vision, the health of people who have to deal with situations of weakness and reduced autonomy. 

The priority of the Institute is to provide people the best quality of life possible in relation to their mental and physical health through the respect of the actual context in which they live.

Considered that old connection between social engagement and cultural commitment, Fondazione Venezia – Servizi alla Persona decides to follow the management of cultural and artistic heritage of great value, property of IRE.

As in the past we used to decorate the seats allocated to welfare and charity with the work of the great masters, so the Foundation believes that today it is right to pursue the enhancement of masterpieces of artists that once decorated those places. 

This operation begins with the reopening to the public of the Scala Contarini del Bovolo. Thanks to the latest renovation, whose preliminary draft was designed by the architect Paolo Faccio, this architectural gem has regained its former glory and it is now ready to be reunited with the surrounding urban context.

The restitution of these goods to the community is essential for their conservation and promotion: through its use, public art found its sense of accomplishment, because art is inseparable from the enjoyment of the beholder and from the joy of who is enhanced by it.

Scala Contarini del Bovolo, the hidden treasure of Venice

Hidden in a maze of streets and canals, very close to Campo Manin, along one of the main tourist routes in Venice (railway – Academy), appears an architectural gem characterized by a style that is among Renaissance, Gothic and Byzantine: the Scala Contarini del Bovolo .

The spiral staircase most impressive and valuable in Venice is a perfect synthesis of different styles: Renaissance (for the use of some elements such as the capitals), Gothic (for the construction technique) and Venetian-Byzantine (for the form).

It was commissioned by Pietro Contarini probably around the end of 1400 in order to decorate the facade of the adjacent Palace of San Paternian owned by an illustrious Venetian family. The realization of this work, in fact, did not have at first a functional purpose, but consisted mainly of an act of prestige and aimed mainly to a further growth in the popularity of the family.

The creation of the scale had such a wide appeal that have led citizens to choose a nickname for that branch of the family for which, since that time has been used the nickname Contarini del Bovolo (referring to the particular shape of the staircase "to snail shell" which in Venetian is said precisely "bovolo").

The palace and the staircase

The Palace has known several owners in its long existence; a stylistic examination puts the first constructions in the mid- 1300s, a time when the Doge Andrea Contarini was in charged, one of the most powerful members of the family Contarini Branch San Paternian.

Initially, it was owned by Morosini, later the building was sold to the Contarini as dowry by the marriage of Caterina and Zuanne Contarini Morosini.  Towards the end of 1400 a special spiral staircase built by Pietro Contarini, son of Zuanne and Caterina, probably enriched the palace. It is true that, on the occasion of "redecima" in 1514, Pietro Contarini claimed that he was living in a residential house located in San Paternian.

In 1518, the year of his death, Pietro left the property to his daughter Contarina, where she lived with her husband and children. Another member of the family of successive generations will declare to live in the same building. 

The ownership of the property remained to the Contarini’s family throughout the eighteenth century, however, gaining the name of Minelli following the marriage between Elisabetta Contarini and Giovanni Minelli. The last heirs of the family Minelli sell their shares to Dominic Emery Toulon.

The palace was coming from a period in which was assigned to Arnaux Marseille called the Maltese who had opened a motel which still derives the name of the street (Calle delle Locande/ Calle of the motels) that leads to arrive to the small square of the Palace .

Since 1849 the property is linked to the "Foundation Emery" managed by the Fraternal of the poor of San Luca who assisted the needs of the parish. Since then the history of the building is linked with the story of assistance care in Venice: before the building came under the management of the Congregation of Charity and became the administrative center; then it is transferred to the Institute Manin changing jurisdiction from welfare to recovery.

This step is crucial because it will make that the Palazzo Contarini move to the IRE (Institution for recovery and Education) and will become in the manager of all institutions of refuge around the city.

From 1937, the building will become a branch of ECA (Municipal Assistance Entity) until 1975, the year when the duties of assistance will go to the district; while from 1939 the same will also host the offices of the IRE, that always in the '75 abandon it to leave space for restoration work.

The IRE, in addition to the social function, has a very important cultural function having inherited an artistic and architectural heritage of the ancient charities. During the Serenissima (Republic of Venice), in fact, the art was accompanied by social commitment, beautifying and enriching the different branches of the brotherhoods charitable. In this context we find the work of prominent artists and architects such Longhena for the Church of Beggars and the Church of Ospedaletto, Palladio for the Zitelle Church and Derelitti, Palma the younger for the Oratory of the Crociferi, Jacopo Guarana for frescoes in the Ospedaletto music room, Tiepolo for the Church of Mercy and the Church of Ospedaletto.

Who created the staircase?

The Scala Contarini del Bovolo was commissioned by Pietro Contarini roughly towards the end of 1400 for reasons of prestige and social success, as a decorative element of the adjacent building, at the time his place of residence. Even today there is nothing certain about the identification of the designer of the staircase, but there are two main hypotheses. 

The tradition has attributed the authorship to Giovanni Candi based on some information obtained from his last will and testament. Here, in fact, he appears as a creditor of a large quantity of money against Pietro Contarini. 

This first proposal, however, has some limits: firstly, it is not said that Giovanni has its own credit for the construction work of the staircase; secondly, Candi was not named " architect”, instead it is seen as a "joiner", position addressed for a person who perform purely carpentry and joinery, and it seems strange that Contarini had entrusted a work of such great importance to a carpenter. Moreover, in this case, it could be justified some architectural inconsistencies in the construction and that classicism, a bit medieval in the style, still far from the Renaissance consciousness.

Lea Salvatori Rizzi, in a recent study, advanced in the alternative hypothesis of Giorgio Spavento, an important architect of that time. It seems strange indeed that Contarini had not consulted an expert for a work of such great value. Incidentally Spavento had contact the Contarini of San Paternian for the design of the Church of San Salvador.

There is lack of evidence in relation to the intervention on the building, however there are stylistic similarities by comparison with other works of his creation: as the neo Byzantine character, the precision, the essential decorative without plastic elements and accentuated by the use of brick. In addition to the most significant work of Spavento, the Fondaco dei Tedeschi, the architect uses square pillars instead of columns supporting the arches on the ground floor, the choice made for the Scala Contarini del Bovolo. 

It is likely that the work was not well seen by the government of Venice for the huge outlay which entailed: interventions of this type, in fact, on one hand the impoverished local economy and on the other hand, the idea of taking some risks creating dangerous competitions between different families. The main cost for the realization of the staircase is due to the materials used: Istrian stone of excellent quality.

An architectural gem

The property is developed widely in height above the average of the Venetian palaces. This required great technical skills by manufacturers because the property was completely perforated by arches and lodges. In addition there was the need to adapt to an existing building, as well as the problem of unstable foundations due to the peculiarities of the Venetian subsoil. 

Another obstacle resulted from the large range of construction, which greatly increased static and architectural difficulties.

The reference to the Tower of Pisa is immediate and we can compare that the technique used does not indicate that the Renaissance conscience, but it is distinguished by an original reinterpretation of classicism. 

The staircase is the finest example of the neo- Byzantine Venice: here it was established a New Renaissance, in contrast to the taste of Lombards; Tuscans and Roman trends; and the model of Byzantine Ravenna buildings.

The Scala Contarini del Bovolo is composed of two sections linked together, a loggia and a cylindrical tower. 

The gallery is open to the outside with large Renaissance arches, three per floor and decreasing height so that those on the top floor prove half of those on the ground floor. This trick of perspective gives the work a greater height.

The peculiarity of the staircase is to make the rest of the ground floor arches on square pillars instead of columns. 

The cylindrical tower has 26 meters high and has a diameter of 4.70 meters. It sets on a central pillar around which are superimposed 80 monolithic steps that ascend counterclockwise.

The column ends on the top floor with a lookout with decorative Istrian stone. The steps have a trapezoidal shape and end with a ring that slips in the central pin; a layer of molten lead evens the contact surfaces between the various elements. The first flight of stairs rises straight and rests on arches of different sizes and is contained in the first lodge. 

The capitals are characterized by a very original cut: the four spirals are connected as many acanthus leaves very simple and with little relief. 

A small flight of stairs rebuilt in 800 allows access to the lookout. The wooden roof that is located inside the dome is 1874. Originally it had a lower frame and tiles.

It is important to point out the interior of the helical staircase, the alternation of empty and full of taste, typical Venetian and the contrast between the perforated facing the courtyard and the brick facing of the building. The contrast is given by the surface of the red - brown brick Gothic ancestry and the white of the ribs in Istrian stone.

The spiral staircase most impressive and valuable in Venice is a perfect synthesis of different styles: Renaissance (for the use of some elements such as the capitals), Gothic (for the construction technique) and Venetian-Byzantine (the form).

The nineteenth-century restorations

The first restoration works date back to the second half of the 800: the building was in a poor state of conservation and this led to several campaigns of consolidation, also accompanied by distributional changes and reforms of the perforated patterns. 

It also intervened at the staircase: the cracked steps were affected by the implementation of grappa iron and damaged the central column was enclosed by a wall pillar.

Unfortunately, the interventions in the nineteenth-century were gradually canceled by the oxidation of the metal elements and the consequences induced by the static of a hardening masonry pillar, which embraced the middle column of the ladder.  It can be also added the degradation of the stone material.

The restoration of the Minnesota Chapter of the Word Monuments Found

In 1979, the Minnesota Chapter of the Word Monuments Found financed the restoration of the Scala Contarini del Bovolo in the context of the International Campaign for the Safeguarding of Venice. 

The restoration project, developed in 1980 by architect Mario Piana of the Superintendent of Environmental and Architectural Heritage, was entrusted to the Venetian Building of Engineer Todeschini for structural reinforcement, and the company Lithos for intervention on the stone. 

This intervention was designed with the idea of restoring the monument to a condition close to the original one, by searching for methods and materials that behave the least possible tampering of historical material. 

The idea is also to remove the causes of the static flow, such as the replacement of the iron clamps as stainless steel elements and the removal of the pillar masonry, finishing with the cleaning and restoration of stone parts. 

This restoration won the prize Torta in 1992 for the quality and competence demonstrated in its implementation. 

The last restoration and restitution to the community

The last renovation of Palazzo Contarini by the Institute of Recovery and Education has provided a unique opportunity to return to the usability of the staircase security most beautiful in the world. 

The drafting of the final project dates back to 2006 and the executive to 2009.

The project for Palazzo Contarini del Bovolo was based on studies and very advanced analysis. 

In relation to the investigations carried out, it was possible to identify some internal partitions and ceilings made ​​recently that deprive the spaces of their characters, complicating the paths and creating a disadvantage position in the perception of the space. The project involved the elimination of these elements in order to redefine the redistribution of routes and to find more consistency.

It was ensured a clear division of the entrances and the spaces between IRE, City of Venice and the area open to visitors, a distinction also determined by security issues.

The intervention consists mainly in a new staircase connecting all floors of the IRE, placed in the other side of the Palace; in order to do this, it has been studied a finishing touch that recalls the materials of the lagoon through the transparency and the colors of blown glass sheets supported by a metal structure which also contains the elevator shaft.

The construction of the new staircase meets functional requirements, it is characterized as new and distinctive element of the restoration and aims to evoke some materials and counterpoint between the Palace and the outdoor staircase. Also the distribution of the structure was the most conservative possible of the existing construction, identifying two main distribution plans.

The interventions of consolidation of the horizontal planes are summarized in conditions of deformability and the increase of some elements. Structural improvements resulting from combined actions such as the reduction of the light through the onboard network, the increase of rigidity with reinforcements with double plank and plank nails, and replacement with wood restorations. The horizontal planes such stiffened have been linked to the perimeter walls with metal chains isolated and profile system steel whose purpose was to distribute stress on the masonry. In case, it has found valuable elements, consolidation solutions have been abandoned in favor of conservation. The other interventions were more conservatives: the identification, preservation, and integration of historic finishes (especially some decorations dating back to the early stages of the building that they encounter while on the external elevation at the staircase), the security and consolidation of all stone elements. 

The construction site was an important moment of knowledge of the Palace, whose future preservation can refer to material collected and processed; these insights have also addressed some design choices, related for example to highlight some past phases of the construction of the Palace. 

Additionally, this last intervention has given back to the Scala Contarini its main function: it has constituted a chance to give utility to a unique work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a donation, there is another way you can contribute to our cause, share this campaign on your Facebook page and Twitter, in this way you will help us spread our initiative!
